results.description:
Walk off all that extra food!


this is on, rain or shine or snow. See you there.

We'll do two laps, approximately five miles.

Few things relieve stress better than a some exercise on a nice winter evening.

Let's join some local walking groups for a stroll in a beautiful setting.

If you've still got some energy left, we'll be heading to Mt. Auburn Cemetery, then out to lunch at a local eatery. 

Parking on Huron Avenue is easy, since the "Permit Parking" rules don't apply on Sunday - just park in any spot on Huron Ave, there will be plenty of them.

results.description:
We had so much fun last year that we just had to do this again! Join us for our 2nd annual Christmas Day double-feature with a break for yummy fuel in between. You're welcome to come for just one movie, or both, or the whole shebang.

=============================================


                                        Movie #1 -- Matinee

                           We will see the 1:15 pm showing of

                       >>> Buy ticket for 1:15 show NOW <<<

Running time:  2 hrs 4 min

Synopsis:  The story of a family across four generations and the woman who rises to become founder and matriarch of a powerful family business dynasty. Official website

                                        Movie #2 -- Evening


                      We will see the 7:00 pm, 2D version of

                       >>> Buy ticket for 7:00 show NOW <<<

Running time:  2 hrs 56 min

Synopsis:  The passengers, bounty hunter John Ruth and his fugitive Daisy Domergue, race towards the town of Red Rock where Ruth, known in these parts as “The Hangman,” will bring Domergue to justice. Official website

=============================================

                           ??? HOW DOES THIS WORK ??? 

First, you'll need to buy your ticket(s). A link for purchasing tickets from Fandango will appear under each movie poster when tickets are available for that show. If there is no link that says "Buy ticket for x:xx show NOW," that means tickets are not available yet. Check back daily or wait for my email blast.

Then, we'll meet at the AMC about an hour before the matinee. That means for "Joy," look for us on the 2nd floor at a table by the windows at 12:15; we'll move into the auditorium at least 30 minutes before the movie starts in order to commandeer the best block of seats possible. For "The H8teful Eight," look for us on the 2nd floor by the windows between 6:00 and 6:30.

>>> I *highly recommend* that when tickets become available, you buy yours online. You can wait until you get to the theater if you'd like, but if the show is sold out before you get there, you'll be out of luck. Also, if your plans change, Fandango will allow you to swap your ticket for another show or issue a credit/refund. <<<

IF YOU WANT TO SIT WITH or NEAR THE GROUP -- please get to the AMC on time; in other words, within 1/2 hour of the start time listed for this event. It's not possible to save seats for a large group of people who haven't shown up yet so we don't try because even if you do show up on time, we can't guarantee that we'll all be able to sit together (this is especially true for blockbuster action films and highly anticipated movies that generate waiting lines). You have a better chance of sitting with us if you are with us when we move into the auditorium. It is your  responsibility to get to the theater and locate our group. Everything you need to know to find us is right here on this page. Cell phone coverage is spotty at best inside the AMC building. Don't rely on sending a text message or posting to the Meetup page to locate the group. 

COULDN'T FIND US -- so you sat by yourself for the movie? No worries. You can still join us for food.

AFTER THE MATINEE -- we'll gather in the hallway outside the auditorium. Once we've taken a head-count of all the hungry people in our group, we'll leave the AMC and walk to the restaurant.

>>> If you didn't join us for the matinee but you've got a ticket for the evening film and you want to join us for dinner, you're welcome to wait for the group outside the entrance of the AMC between 3:30 and 3:45. <<<

We'll be at the restaurant for anywhere from 1-1/2 to 3 hours, depending upon the size of our party, how busy the restaurant is, etc.

AFTER DINING and PAYING OUR BILL -- those of us who are going to see the evening movie will walk back to the AMC together. 

============================================= 

                        $$$ ABOUT DINNER AND MONEY $$$

We'll be eating at an Asian restaurant in Chinatown, walking distance from the AMC. Most of the Chinatown restaurants that will be open on Christmas Day don't take reservations, even for large groups. Be prepared to wait a bit for a table once we get to our destination.

Managing a restaurant event is so much easier if everyone brings cash, so please plan ahead:

(1) BRING CASH.

(2) Everyone will pay for their own food/drinks; but because we are a group, your order will be included on one check for the entire group. Why? Because (a) most restaurants prefer a single check for groups of 8 people or more; and (b) we are a MOVIE group, so we need to get back to the theater to stake our claim on another awesome block of seats. One check, with everyone paying their portion in cash, means we will get out of the restaurant more quickly and be back at the theater in plenty of time. [Organizer reserves the right to allow separate checks if there are less than 8 diners.]

(3) PLEASE BRING CASH!

(4) Tax on food in Boston is 6.25%. Minimum tip expected for a group at Boston restaurants is 18%. Plan to add 25% to your food and drink total to cover YOUR share of BOTH tax and tip.

(5) !!! DON'T FORGET TO BRING CASH !!!

=============================================

QUESTIONS? It's unlikely that it wasn't covered above, but feel free to post it in the conversation section below and a Boston Movie Group veteran will answer.

See you on Christmas Day!

Anor
results.name: Xmas Day Dinner-and-a-Movie Double-Feature

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball.

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.

This is to give you time to cook something to bring with you to eat as nothing will be open on the street. Bribes will be greedily devoured but we do have refridgerators and a microwave to store and heat your food.

results.description:
Many relocated young professionals in big cities can find themselves without Christmas plans for several reasons:

• Family is too far away to visit

• Religious differences

• Too crazy at work/not enough vacation time

• Not wanting to get gouged by the airlines after already paying for overpriced flights a month before for Thanksgiving

• Bad experiences with reindeer and/or elves

So, I've talked to a few people from Pedro's Friends who fit one of these criteria, and we want to tough it out together.  I celebrated by first Christmas on my own last year with Chinese food and a movie, but in this Catholic town, and many of the Chinese food places close pretty early.

Nothing is planned yet, but we'll definately be doing something. I'll make the details finalized when I get the interest level of people, and see who is interested in what. Please don't by shy about hitting up the comment section on your thoughts, ideas and interest level. Here are some of the options:

• Chinese food and a movie (I'll confirm what's open and when they close)

• Call around to see if any bars are open

• Have a small Christmas/holiday party of our own with awkward sweaters, carol singing, eggnog, other stuff too, and maybe even a Secret Santa exchange

• Have a crazy dance party in celebration of Saturnalia
results.name: Spend your Christmas Looking for Pedro

results.description:
A few of us will be around Boston for Christmas with no real plans. If you are around and want something fun to do Christmas day, come join us for dinner at Fogo De Chao! 

Located not far from the Copley T-stop, Fogo is an Brazilian steakhouse that features an unlimited salad bar and fancy cuts of meat for a set price. The cost is around $60 + tax. Even if you don't eat meat, the salad bar is amazing and there is an option to do just the salad bar for a cheaper price. What better way to spend the holiday than good food and good company, right?


This is an RSVP event. So please be sure to keep your availability up to date. Much appreciated.
results.how_to_find_us: I'll provide contact details the day of
results.name: A Very Meatup Xmas: Fogo De Chao

results.description:
To all those who responded yes to Xmas, then Xmas Eve....I'm sorry to change this again....truly. But If you read my post about the group cancelled for tomorrow night, I've been under the weather with gastro issues AGAIN...doctor said NO spicy or saucy foods til 12/25, minimum...So I have to change this event back to Christmas Day..so sorry but hope you can still make it...Kindly update your RSVP....

Many of us who are celebrating the holiday and season with our friends, but who celebrate Hanukkah or Solstice or Kwanza, or nothing at all, may not have plans on Xmas.

Don't spend it alone...Let's do our 'usual' and get together for dinner at Bamboo next to the Holiday Inn in Dedham.

Let's talk about the upcoming New Year of 2016...What's 'new for you' in the New Year? 

Do you make 'resolutions' or any kinds of new goals? If so, do you keep them? 

I make them and complete some of them, at least in the past few years. Am determined to pare down the list and make it more relevant, realistic, etc...Last year I promised myself I'd get my little apartment more organized ..(Those of you who know me, know what I mean! LOL)..and I did start that project, still ongoing, but taking the right steps...For 2016, I am going to continue that, but also find a way to exercise. The rest I'll share over dinner....WOuld love to hear how you approach a new year....

Over the past few years we've had a great time together on Xmas, so join us!
results.name: Talk about What's Going To Be "New" for You in the New Year

results.description:
We'll walk for a couple of hours at a moderate/fast pace!    

The Town Forest is a 290 acre site located in the northwestern part of  town. It can be accessed by main entrances on Fox Run Lane (off  of Franklin St.) and Strout Ave (off of Grove St.). There is an additional  entrance at the end of Roma Lane.  Street parking is available off of Fox Run Ln. and  along Grove St., in front of Strout Ave (this road is usually chained off to general traffic).
The Town Forest has an extensive trail system, many of  which are fairly flat roads. Most of these trails are  suitable for walks or bikes, but be aware that many  trails go through</a> swampy areas that may be wet and muddy,  depending on the time of year.
Among the many natural features of the Town Forest are large  Pine trees, numerous vernal pools, and part of the Ipswich River.
The Town Forest was created in April, 1930 when over 100,000 red and white pine, spruce,  balsam, and scotch pine trees were planted by local Boy Scouts and other  interested citizens. The "pine plantations" are now mature forests, over 60 years old. Many species of birds and animals live in the town forest currently, and the acidic soil  allows pink and white ladyslippers to grow here.  

 Protect yourself against deer ticks and dress in layers.

No dogs and no guests are allowed on hikes. Have your guest join the group so they can sign the Liability Waiver. Don't ask; there are no exceptions.

By clicking the "Yes" option on the RSVP link you are agreeing to the Liability Waiver as stated below:  

Remember: Your Event Organizers are volunteers. You are solely responsible for your own safety and enjoyment. As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following: this activity involves inherent risks that can cause property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death to participants and/or others; you assume all risk associated with this activity; you are responsible for having the necessary knowledge, skills, abilities, clothing, and equipment to safely participate in this activity; you have read and agree to adhere to the safety standards detailed @<a href="http://www.hikesafe.com/">http://www.hikesafe.com/; the organizer(s) of this activity is a volunteer; and you for yourself, your heirs, executors, and administrators release, hold harmless, and indemnify organizer(s) and all members of this group from any and all claims for property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death - including those caused by negligence and/or other reason.
results.how_to_find_us: We will meet at the main entrance at the at the start of Strout Ave (off of Grove St.)
results.name: Trek  in Reading Town Forest

results.description:
Every Saturday morning at 10:00 AM we gather for a fun, calming group run at the Chestnut Hill Reservoir. Both walkers and runners are welcome. Our main goal is to socialize and support one another!

The Boston Bulldogs is a co-ed non-profit running club founded to support those battling addiction and in recovery, those who have been affected by addiction and their supporters.

We welcome and encourage runners of all levels – dreamers, beginners, as well as those with running experience, past or present. Our volunteer runners will be there to coach you at your current level, and help you meet your goals. We might even be able to help with running gear if needed. 

We meet twice weekly at the Chestnut Hill Reservoir (Cleveland Circle/Reservoir Green Line C or D train) -- on Saturday mornings at 10:00 AM and Thursday evenings at 6:30 PM. We first gather in front of the Cleveland Circle Starbucks, before heading over to the reservoir. See you there!

If you are interested in becoming a member or a volunteer, in making a contribution to the Club, in sponsoring a runner in recovery, or in learning more about the Boston Bulldog educational wellness/running program, contact us at:

• Website - BostonBulldogsRunning.com

• Email - [masked] 

• Phone -[masked]
results.how_to_find_us: We will start gathering outside the Starbucks at Cleveland Circle around 9:45am... see you then!
results.name: Saturday's Group Fun Run

results.description:
We'll run from the cafe to the river path, go west to Prospect Street, and double back along the river. Finishing up with one loop around the common to make it an even 2 miles. Since it's an out and back we can spread out at different paces to accommodate beginner to advanced runners, but still start and finish together.  Coffee/goodies at the cafe afterwards is also optional but highly recommended :-).

This is a great way to get into running, introduce your friends to the group, or just start your Saturday on a high note.  All ages and levels welcome.

If you are hesitating to come, keep in mind that nearly every week we have beginning runners who use a run/walk/run technique.  If you take walk breaks you will probably not be alone, and it's the best way to get into running, so come on out!
results.name: Beginner run from Cafe on the Common 2 miler-all levels

Hello Singles! Let's have a casual get together where we can talk, relax, and have great food. Check gyrokebabhouse.com out on Yelp.com and you will find all positive reviews. I ordered two lamb dishes that were very good. The flat breads are large and fresh. There is a soup and salad offering for $10 and each of the entrees are about the same. Make no mistake about it, this is fast food. You walk in and place your order, call in, or order on the web site. It is first come, first served, so the person asking first whether by phone or at the counter is first served. I got my order in 10 minutes, but it could take longer. You decide what would work best for you. Feel free to draw up a chair at one end of the table and move to say hello at the other end of the table. I feel good about helping out a brand new business in our area. They note that they offer Mediterranean, Turkish, and Halal foods.

And head to the Boylston street entrance of Boston Public Library. Which is on the side of the library and NOT THE FRONT. Though the whole entrance is in renovation,  you can still able enter through the entrance. Head to the second floor and you should be able to find us.

results.description:
NOTE: In order to ensure a more accurate head-count of participation (and to avoid confusion over having TWO online sign-up areas (Meetup & LLBean), all participants should now sign up at http://www.llbean.com/mansfield

Join L.L. Bean Mansfield as we celebrate the first hike of the winter season on Saturday December 26. This will be a sunset and twilight hike to Sundown Ledge in F. Gilbert Hills State Forest. We’ll meet at 3:15PM in the main parking area at park HQ at 45 Mill Street in Foxboro. Our hike is planned for an afternoon kickoff so our arrival at Sundown Ledge will be timed to view the sun as it slips below the western horizon at 4:19PM. Consider bringing a thermos bottle of your favorite hot beverage to enjoy at Sundown Ledge as we watch the close of another day. Bring a flashlight and/or headlamp for use in the gathering darkness as we next pay a visit to the dolman before the return trip to our vehicles. This hike should run about 3 hours and cover about 4 miles in distance. If we need to make changes to the hike mandated by snow, poor road or weather conditions those changes (or cancellation/rescheduling) will be posted to this site.

The minimum age for attending is 8 (Children 8-15 yrs must have a participating adult with them, 16-17 yrs must have a parent/guardian sign participant agreement but do not need to attend).

Please dress appropriately for the weather conditions.

Dressing in layers works best.

Wear appropriate footwear for hiking.

Please bring water, snacks and any personal medicines and gear you may need as well. These outings are free but you are responsible to have everything you need.

A camera and/or binoculars are always a welcome addition.

Leashed, people friendly, well socialized outdoor dogs are welcome at this venue.

Please arrive 15 minutes before hand because we want to get started on time.

If you have any trouble finding our meetup location please feel free to call before the event kicks off. Andy’s cell phone is[masked]-4503.

Please sign up at http://www.llbean.com/mansfield
results.how_to_find_us: Look for　Andy’s Green Honda Pilot with the "L.L. Bean Mansfield Outing Program" banner hanging on the side!
results.name: Winter Solstice Sunset,Twilight Hike to Sundown Ledge with L.L.Bean Mansfield

results.description:
Last weekend the photo shoot was so much fun I have decided to offer it again right away. The weather looks warm and nice on Saturday so why not grab your camera, get out of the house and come see the lights of the city in a creative way.

Skaters on Frog Pond against the Boston Skyline. Photo by part one participant Swati B. The assignment was to capture the blur motion of skaters in motion with stillness of the lights in the background. She got it just right!

Boston is all decked out for the holiday season with more lights than ever. In this workshop we will focus on the three key skills necessary for night photography. The weather looks clear for Saturday the 26th so lets get out there and enjoy the magical beauty of the night. 


Trees wrapped in lights.Working with positive and negative spaces for creative composition and dramatic impact.

Photo of Boston Skyline take by participant Deb. D. in part one. I knew the day would come when the photos taken by the participants would be even better than mine. Beautiful composition, proper exposure and starburst effects.

Some of the topics we will cover in the program:

1. How to get the proper camera settings to capture the stunning lights against the dramatic night sky. 

2. How to  composition to balance the different zones of the image using creative strategies including and beyond the rule of thirds.

3. How to work  with reflections of lights in water and windows to add depth and mystery to your images.

We will photograph a range of subjects including trees, architecture, and people. 

You do need a tripod for this workshop since we will be experimenting with show shutter speeds. You don't need to know how to set your shutter speed, I will help you.

Photo by Dianne Ward participant in Part One This image by Dianne is perfectly composed and exposed. Notice the beautiful star burst effect she achieved by using a small aperture opening and slow shutter speed. I will teach you how to do this and where to take this shot.

The warm weather means they have not yet drained the water from the pond in the Boston Gardens so this allows for some really stunning photos of reflections. I took this one just now with my iPhone but can't wait to go back and try it again with my camera.

Architecture and blur motion capture. Beautiful contradiction of stillness and motion. Join us to learn what settings to use. 

Photo By Lisa Watchmaker participant in Part One. We will have fun working with light trails and zoom exposures. 

Abstract images using slow shutter speed to capture light.

If this sounds like fun, I hope you will join us. I will be away for a few weeks after this class.  Knowing how to photography night scenes is an essential skill to add to your knowledge base as a growing photographer so I hope you will join us.  Take a break from the holiday stress and enjoy the beauty of a night out in Boston!  I am limiting this program to 12. You do not need to have taken part one to take part to. You will need take your camera of the Auto setting and I can help you with this step.

Hope to see you on Saturday! 

Suzanne

Trees at night magical quality captured with available light.

Even though the address is Park Plaza, the easy entrances are on Charles Street (by Starbucks, 12 Charles St South - NOT the one on Beacon Hill) and Stuart Street (by Dunkin Donuts). 


We traditionally have a large social meetup twice each month. This gives everyone an opportunity to come and make new friends, practice their Japanese or English, and spend time with a bunch of interesting people from around the Boston area and overseas.  This meetup may be cancelled if there are not many RSVPs.


Come on by, relax, practice in either language of your choice, and enjoy being part of our growing community!

Whoever is interested generally goes out to Chinatown for dinner afterwards, to eat family style - cost usually around $12-20/person (not including any drinks other than tea/water, for which people pay their own way).

results.description:
{We'll share the 2015 that was, and start the process of creating the fantastic 2016 that will be.  Like any party, we'll chat and eat, and we'll enjoy one another, and, like any HeartBeat Salon, we'll bring consciousness to where we have been and to where we are going.}


This Evening We Will ....

... celebrate the year that was, what we accomplished, and what we started.  And we will start to turn our attention to our next steps, what we might focus on next year, and where we might be headed such that our year will be well-lived.

And we'll leave this party appreciating the blessings of our past year, and excited about what the upcoming year promises.

To Bring ...

This is a potluck dinner party, so bring something easy and tasty to eat.  (If you do not like to prepare or buy food, throw $10 per person in the pot.) 

[Optional]: Bring a friend.

To Prepare ....

1)  What has gone great this year? 
2) What could have gone better?
3) What vision do you have for next year?  

Our Leader This Evening

This is a Route 128 South Heartbeat Salon community event.  All of us will share our year that was and start to create our year that will be.

results.description:
Full Moon Gong: with Dharam Singh, Guruatma Kaur, and Siri Tapa Kaur

New Moon Gong: with Guruatma Kaur

 What to expect: Preparing ourselves with a Kundalini Yoga set we will create a body-mind balance for change and healing. While in this state the sound waves of the gong and bowls induce an extended state of effortless meditation and relaxation that facilitates the movement of prana through the body and psyche for healing. In this way, the gong is a tool that magnifies and focuses the power of the yoga experience.   


We will finish with tea, treats, and joy! 

Please bring a thick blanket or cushion to lie on and a shawl to cover with!   

“The Gong is the first and last instrument for the human mind, there is only one thing that can supersede and command the human mind, the sound of the Gong. It is the first sound in the Universe, the sound that created the Universe. It’s the basic creative sound. To the mind, the sound of the gong is like a mother and father that gave it birth. The mind has no power to resist a gong that is well played.”  -Yogi Bhajan, Master of Kundalini Yoga   

Yoga & Gong: Guruatma Kaur: An IKYTA certified teacher and devoted student of Yogi Bhajan, Guruatma Kaur has been enthusiastically teaching Kundalini Yoga since 1979. She is lovingly dedicated to encouraging clarity, excellence, and relaxation into one’s True Self.  

Gong:  Dharam Singh began an exploration of sound as a saxophonist and flutist in the Bronx, NYC - an environment immersed in the rich music and culture of Africa by way of the Caribbean, Boriqua, African American and the counter culture, which gave him a multicultural perspective on musical language.   His passion for the transformative power of sound and music has found a place in the use of the Gong as he came to develop a unifying aural language that removes the separation between Head and Heart, Body and Soul. It is these frequencies, tones and harmonics, already given by Nature that he simply lives to share.  Dharam is a long time student of Yogi Bhajan and a resident of Guru Ram Das Ashram, where he is the go-to guy for anything related to Gong Yoga, including buying one - www.gongsongs.com He is part of the 'three-some' that leads the monthly Full Moon Gong event 

Meditation: Siri Tapa Kaur, a Reiki Master, Sat Nam Rasayan Practitioner, and certified Kundalini Yoga Teacher lives a life committed to being healthy, happy, and available to all. Everyone who knows her is touched by her open-hearted, compassionate mother energy. 

Note: in case of any date discrepancy between this Meetup and the website, please believe the website!
results.how_to_find_us: Yoga at the Ashram is located at the Baba Siri Chand Yoga Center at Guru Ram Das Ashram, 368 Village St in Millis, MA 02054
results.name: Full and New Moon Yoga, Gongs, and Meditation

results.description:
This will be our sixth trip into Baxter State Park during the winter - last year we were successful in our efforts to climb North Brother, Fort, South Brother, and Coe. This year's trip will be a follow-up to our partially successful trip two years ago when we got to the summit of Katahdin but had to forgo Hamlin and the Knife Edge because of bad weather. We are going back to finish what we started in 2013.

This isn't like the summer when you can drive your car into the park - the roads are all closed and its 12+ miles just to reach the summer trailhead (Roaring Brook). The long approach makes it easier to do this trip over 4-5 days. While we can stay in lean tos or tents we opt for the bunkhouses at Roaring Brook and Chimney Pond.

The planning for this five-day trip started last winter when people expressed an interest in going with us this year. Because this trip happens very early in the winter season and requires a strong, cohesive group, it's important to pick the right people to go. The only way to get an understanding of what people can handle in the snow and the cold and to learn more about their personality is to hike with them during the previous winter season.

We will post our stories and our pictures here. If what you see seems like fun and you would like to join us for a similar trip (or perhaps other parts of Baxter or the Adirondacks) during winter[masked] let us know when you hike with us during the next few months.
results.name: Katahdin, Hamlin, and the Knife Edge in Winter

venue.name: The New England Center for Homeless Veterans

results.description:
I volunteer a couple of times a month serving lunch at the shelter. Great group of men and women who have served our country and have come back needing a little help. The Center, which was started by a Veteran, provides housing, health care, social services, food, as well as a multitude of other services for our returning heroes. They have volunteer groups come in on weekends and do breakfast service. We don't provide the food, just smiles and friendly faces. The serving starts at 7:15am and we would be done by around 9.  We have gone as a group several times and hope to keep this up monthly, there's a limit to 6 servers each time. It's really a wonderful time. Some of the ladies asked about baking/bringing something. I also spoke with the head of the kitchen....just avoid things with nuts because of allergies. Hope to see you all then! We can carpool, it's near the Orange line and if you drive in you can park right in front. Also remember a hat, you need to have your head/hair covered to serve.

 My telephone number if you have any questions or have a last minute change to status is[masked]

2 things:
1. Since this is a popular event, I'd like to ask that you only sign up only if you are able to get up early on a Sunday.  There will be several Sundays throughout the year I'll actually take myself off as well so that opens up one spot. On the days I cook, I'll also open it up to have 7 servers so that more can come.
2. To prevent the # of no shows we've had, I'm going to just let everyone know that if you know show, I will remove you from future volunteer opportunities with the Center. I've hated the times when due to no shows, the Vets have had to step in to help, especially because there are often individuals that were on the wait list and didn't have the opportunity to show. If you cannot attend, please RSVP no ahead of time, or at the very least, just call or text me if you aren't well the morning of the shift, just so I know and can get them to provide help when I get there. My telephone # is[masked]-1526. Those letting me know that they can't make a day ahead of time won't be considered a no show.

Thank you for your ongoing support. I appreciate it and I know that the Veterans do as well.
results.name: Volunteer and serve breakfast at the New England Center for Homeless Veterans

results.description:
Any plans for Sun. morning after Christmas?

 How about standing atop the summit of one of Breakheart Reservation's seven rocky hills during a six mile hike (approximate) with your fellow trekkers?

Breakheart Reservation is a 640-acre hardwood forest in Wakefield and Saugus. It is notable for the Ridge Trail with its jagged, rocky outcroppings (Rocky Hill, Crow Hill, Castle Rock, Ash Hill) over 200 feet high, providing vistas of Boston, southern New Hampshire and central Massachusetts.  As stated, we will hike over the Ridge Trail and the Reservation’s other summits, including the former ski slope Breakheart Hill (233’) and Eagle Rock (206’). There will be some steep ascents necessitating scrambling over rocks.

We’ll meet at the parking area at the Northeast Metro Tech, which is located up the hill from Wakefield High School.

Length: Approximately six miles

Level: Intermediate/Advanced Beginner

Duration: Approximately 3.5 hours. However, any time estimate given by an Event Organizer is just that!

This hike is rated intermediate, You should be able to stay with the group going at a pace. of 2.5 MPH.This is a group event and participants are expected to follow the lead, stay together, stop at junctions or summits, and support all participants should circumstances require teamwork. We start together and finish together. If you decide to leave the group at any time, you are on your own. We hike in light rain or showers, but heavy snow or extreme cold weather cancels. Bring water, hiking boots (not sneakers), bug spray and lunch/snacks. Protect yourself against deer ticks and dress in layers.

We are in the winter hiking season. If you don't know what winter hiking entails, please read “Winter Hiking Essentials” in the Pages section of this website. Dress in layers, avoid cotton outerwear and bring microspikes.

No dogs and no guests are allowed on hikes. Have your guest join the group so they can agree to the liability waiver and attend an event.

Please remember that your Event Organizers are volunteers, the event is free and we are all adults. The people who have the best times on these hikes are those who stay loose and roll with things as they happen. If you are expecting Daniel Boone as your leader, you’re barking up the wrong tree. If you need everything to run perfectly, this hike is not for you.

By clicking the "Yes" option on the RSVP link you are agreeing to the Liability Waiver as stated below:
Remember: Your Event Organizers are volunteers. You are solely responsible for your own safety and enjoyment. As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following: this activity involves inherent risks that can cause property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death to participants and/or others; you assume all risk associated with this activity; you are responsible for having the necessary knowledge, skills, abilities, clothing, and equipment to safely participate in this activity; you have read and agree to adhere to the safety standards detailed @ http://www.hikesafe.com/; the organizer(s) of this activity is a volunteer; and you for yourself, your heirs, executors, and administrators release, hold harmless, and indemnify organizer(s) and all members of this group from any and all claims for property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death - including those caused by negligence and/or other reason.

If you want to carpool, put a message in the comment section. To respond, please send that person a direct message by clicking on their profile picture on the right.

For more information and a trail map go to: http://www.mass.gov/eea/agencies/dcr/massparks/region-north/breakheart-reservation.html
Directions to the Northeast Metro Tech parking lot:

Please be aware that these are not the directions to the Reservation's main entrance off the Lynn Fells Parkway. This is the "back door" entrance which provides more parking.

(128) Northbound on Route 128 (I-95) take Exit 39 to North Avenue. Turn right onto North Avenue toward Wakefield. Follow North Avenue to Main Street, cross Main Street to Nahant Street. Follow Nahant Street to Farm Road. Cross Farm Road to Hemlock Road. Wakefield High School will be to your left. Drive up over the hill and enter Northeast's parking area. With The Northeast Baseball Diamond to your left, continue straight into the parking area. 

(128) Southbound on Route 128 (I-95) take Exit 42, Cross under 128 (I-95) to Salem Street where you will turn right onto Salem Street for a short distance to Montrose Avenue where you will turn left onto Montrose. Follow Montrose Avenue to Water Street (Route 129). At this point you will turn right onto Water Street for a short distance, to Farm Road on your left. Follow Farm Road to Hemlock Road. Drive up over the hill and enter Northeast's front parking area. With the Northeast Baseball Diamond to your left, continue straight into the parking area. 

(Rt. 1) Northbound or Southbound on Route 1, take Main Street, Saugus exit off Route 1. Northbound.. at top of exit turn right onto Main Street, Saugus and cross over Route 1. Southbound.. continue to turn right at exit onto Main Street, Saugus. Follow Main Street. Cross Lynn Fells Parkway and continue on Main Street. Stay to your right onto Farm Street. Follow Farm Street to Hemlock Road on your right. You will see a sign directing you on your right. Turn right onto Hemlock Road, drive over the hill and enter Northeast's parking area, with The Northeast's Baseball Diamond to your left.

results.description:
Our services have three parts: Healing Service, a Lecture on a spiritual topic, and Mediumship Spirit Communication. Each part lasts approximately 30 minutes.

The Healing Service gives you the opportunity to receive healing energy that is channeled through one of our Healers. We believe that healing can be channeled through thought to those who need it. This is a very calming experience, whether or not you choose to sit in a healing chair.  We encourage you to send healing to your loved ones, our communities, and Mother Earth.

The Lecture covers a variety of topics ranging from the History of Spiritualism to Inspired Insights. It also includes examples of how Spiritualism is a part of our lives on a daily basis.

Mediumship, or Spirit Communication, is the part of the service where a medium proves that "...the existence and personal identity of the individual continue after the change called death." The medium might be a member of our church or visiting from another the Spiritualist church in the community. We also have mediums from abroad stop in often. While there is only enough time during a service for a few people to receive messages from their deceased loved ones on the Higher side Side of Life, everyone present benefits by witnessing proof of the continuation of life.

At the conclusion of the service everyone is invited to our social hour downstairs for coffee and conversation.﻿

results.description:
WHAT: A pop-up Meetup offering an art break on a holiday weekend. 

WHEN: Sunday, December 27, noon to 5:30 p.m.


WHERE: The Braintree Community Art Center, 1969 Washington St., Braintree, MA 02184. See directions at end of message.  


We'll be in a large, bright, open room near restrooms, sinks, and a kitchen.  Plenty of free parking right outside the door. Restaurants and stores--including a good Michaels--nearby!


AGENDA: None! Come and work on cards, art journals, or any other projects. There's plenty of room to spread out (with even more room on the second floor if needed). 


ATC SWAP: We can do an Artist's Choice swap, if people are interested. Bring your cards!

WHAT OTHER SUPPLIES SHOULD I BRING? There's a suggested list in "All About the NE ATC+ Meetup" (also at the top of the Message Board). But even if you show up empty-handed, that's fine--we'll have some to share.


POTLUCK LUNCH: You're invited, but certainly not required, to bring food or drink for our potluck lunch, or to just bring your own lunch. Or we can order from one of the local eateries.

COST: $10, regardless of when you arrive or depart, to cover costs for space rental, shared supplies, and Meetup fees. Sorry, no partial payments or IOUs. BCAC has an online payment system, but it costs a little to use it, so I recommend paying when you arrive.  Need an ATM? If you're coming in on Route 37 (which most will be), you'll pass by several banks or free-standing ATMs on Route 37 en route to the center. There's also one in the parking lot at Michaels on Pearl Street.  


RSVPs: The RSVP list is our headcount for the day. If you plan to attend, RSVP "yes" to help us with planning and so that you'll receive all Meetup notifications. If your plans change, switch your RSVP to "no" by 12 hours in advance. If you cancel within 12 hours (or RSVP "yes" and don't show up), you'll need to pay $10 anyway to help cover our costs for the day.  


LAST-MINUTE UPDATES: Please check your email in box and the website before leaving for the Meetup. That way, if we have to cancel due to bad weather or any other reason, you'll be sure to get the news.

DIRECTIONS:

For those who know the area: The BCAC is about 3.5 miles south of South Shore Plaza on the same road (Route 37).


--From Route 93: Take Exit 6. Pass the mall on the left. Follow Route 37 about 3.5 miles to the Center. The street name changes several times, so just follow signs for Route 37. It's just before the Holbrook town line.


--By T: Take the Red Line to Braintree; grab a cab at the station (someone else can probably give you a ride back).


--From Route 3: Exit on Union Street (T station will be on your left). Pass T station. Union ends at Washington Street (facing Thayer Academy). Turn left on Washington, then make an immediate right on Central.  Follow Central two blocks to end. Turn left on Franklin (Route 37). Stay on Route 37 for about 2.5 miles. Street name changes several times; just follow signs for Route 37. It's just before the Holbrook town line.


Hope to see you there!
results.name: Holiday Art Break: Sunday, December 27 in Braintree

results.description:
Massive Bowling

Pool/Skeeball/Shuffleboard

Extravaganza!

Hey everyone!

It's time again for our big monthly bowling event at Kings! We always have a great time and we always pack the place. If you've attended before, you know THIS EVENT IS AWESOME, RIGHT?! Of course you do!

FAQ:

Q: Is this really free?
A: Yes! It's really free!

- Free Bowling! 
- Free Shoe Rentals! 
- Free Pool! 
- Free Skeeball! 
- Free Shuffleboard!

Q: Can I bring my kids?
A: Yes! Kids are welcome! I usually have lanes 1 & 2 set up with bumpers for them.

Q: What's the best way to get there?
A: Honestly, taking the T is. See the Getting There section below.

Q: C'mon, this is really all free? What's the catch?
A: Yes, it's really all free and there is no catch! Simply put, I'm awesome. lol : )

RSVP now!

RSVP ETIQUETTE

1. This is a really popular event, and we do count the RSVP's for this, so please RSVP in one group only, as this allows for an accurate count and staff is hired according to this number.

2. RSVP RESPONSIBLY! There are many people in the habit of no-showing and it hurts these events! Don't be that person! Only RSVP if you can go and update your RSVP if you can't make it. You fellow group members and organizers are counting on you to show up. : )

❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤

Get ready for a great time with Boston's best socialites!

See you there… :)

~Matt

P.S. We have the entire Royal Room and bowling lanes 1-10 for this event! Find us inside!

❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤

Getting There:

Taking The T: You can get off at the Hynes Convention Center on the B, C, & D Green Line trains and walk the 2 blocks over, or you can get off at the Prudential Mall station on the E Green Line train and walk through the Pru and the Sheraton to get there.

Driving: Parking can be tough and expensive. There is a garage right next door, but it's $29. You can find on street parking, but that's tough on Sunday mornings. If you want to drive and park, I suggest you get to the area 30-45 minutes early and start looking. Newbury, Hereford, Boylston, and Scotia Streets are all places I look and find parking.

results.description:
Visit the only (so far) cohousing neighborhood in Boston proper, close to the T and the Jamaicaway bike route. Discover why people love living together in sustainable community, blending privacy and neighborly connections, your own kitchen with regular common meals. Meet cohousers young and old, tour the extensive Common House and yard, and map your path to community living. Learn about current and future openings to rent and buy in community.

https://sites.google.com/site/jpcohousinginternet/_/rsrc/1408642841004/config/customLogo.gif?revision=9

This tour repeats: the second Saturday at 2 PM, and the fourth Sunday at 10 AM. Be sure to check the date for the one you are RSVPing to.

About JP Cohousing

We are delighted to have you over to our virtual home! Cohousing is more than just a house-- it's a way of living that makes it easy for you to meet neighbors, make friends, find playmates for the kids, attend parties, or find a movie group. We are situated in the artistic Brookside area of the socially and environmentally-conscious neighborhood of Jamaica Plain in Boston.

In addition to individual fully-equipped units, cohousing members share and enjoy many large common areas because living in cohousing means valuing a sense of community. Our shared facilities include a huge dining hall where we host dinners, parties, and social events; a cozy living room where we show movies and host various clubs; a toddler room for young kids; a rumpus room with exercise equipment, ping-pong and a home theater; office space and meeting room; a laundry room; a large indoor bike storage area; and craft studios. Truly, living in cohousing offers the best of city living, bringing together a diverse and vibrant group of people who value individuality and a sense of community.


Learn more at www.jpcohousing.org

results.description:
Come join us for a late weekend climb!


All levels are welcome! If you are new to climbing, there is a belay class at 1:15PM. Here is the link to sign up: www.centralrockgym.com/bookeo.php?s=watertown. Be advised the belay classes are limited to ten participants, it would be wise to sign up early. 

I will happily belay those who have not climbed before but then it's really important to know how to belay. Come early and take the class then join the group after taking the belay test.

For those of you who already know how to belay, no need to take the class, you just need to pass this gym's belay test when you arrive.

The price is as follows:

Membership: $89/month

Adult Day Pass: $22 

Gear (shoes, harness, belay device): $8 ($5 for members)

Belay class: $15 (free for members)

Belay test: Free

We will meet at the cluster of cubbies on the first floor at 2:00 PM, greet each other, make sure everyone has a group or person to climb with then head off to climb.

I'll be wearing black tank and climbing knickers in case you arrive late and want to search for us. I will also swing by the cubbies every 15 minutes until everyone who signed up has arrived. So, if you are not able to make it or are running late, PLEASE COMMUNICATE on this event's chat .

Hope you can make it! I'm looking forward to meeting more climbers in the area.

Joe

results.description:
The oldest, established, permanent floating Community Walk in Cambridge and environs.

Please join the Fresh Pond Community walkers + five other meetup groups for this delightful sunset walk. 

Let's join 20+ walkers and some other walking groups for:

Over 3 years of reliable walking

Please note that this walk does not start at the same place as the other Fresh Pond walk.

We'll go out to dinner at a local pub or chinese restaurant - you can get a decent dinner for under $10.

Frequently, if we eat too much food, we'll go for another walk.

Come see why this walk is so popular. It's at a great time, the people are friendly, the parking is free -- no permit parking in Cambridge on Sunday, so you can park on Huron or Aberdeen Ave.

You can get there by T easily from Harvard Square, take the 71 OR 73 bus to Aberdeen Ave, then walk to the other end of Aberdeen Ave, and you'll see us there. We'll be next to the bridge, on the pond side of Huron Ave,at the intersection of Aberdeen Ave.

If you're late, and we've already started, start walking counter-clockwise. We'll be walking clockwise, so we'll surely bump into each other. We're the large group of vigorously chatting walkers.

Hope to see you there.

Shangri La is located at 149 Belmont Street, Belmont - please let the host know if you're coming, so we can get the right sized table.

WHAT: ASL Weekly Social
WHEN: EVERY SUNDAY 
TIME: 4:00-6:00PM
WHO: ANYONE is welcome to come by and have a conversation in ASL
WHY: To socialize, have fun, and enjoy chatting in ASL
WHERE:  Panera Bread in Porter Square Shopping Center

NOTE: Every once a while, the location may change. PLEASE look on the website each week for confirmation. THANKS!


To get to the Meetup, take the RED LINE stop OUTBOUND TO ALEWIFE, and stop at PORTER SQ. Panera Bread is right next to Dunkin Donuts. If you're driving, you can park on the street for free on Sundays!

Anyone who loves ASL is welcome to come and be part of the fun! We want to warmly extend an invitation to Deaf people or others fluent/skilled in the language (CODAs for example) to join our group.

This is an easy-going, casual, ASL get-together to meet people who enjoy American Sign Language, who want to brush up on their signing skills, and want to learn more ASL by using it as often as possible.

We strive to have a good time and communicate without using voices. If we need to, we draw or write what we don't know how to sign, and if lots of folks show up, we split up into small groups and mix and mingle, so we can actually see one another clearly, face-to-face and get a good conversation going.

Don't be afraid or shy if you're not "perfect" at ASL, because being "perfect" is not the point of this group. No one expects that everyone will be at the same level, and none of us mind slowing down or repeating what we have signed so that everyone understands.

We all laugh WITH one another as we fumble along, mess things up, and start over again. This isn't an ASL class, since none of us are certified ASL teachers, so there's really no pressure or expectation--other than that we all use ASL to communicate. We all learn from one another!

IF you've taken an ASL/Sign Language class before (or have had exposure to someone who uses the language) and know the basics (alphabet, numbers 1-20, and even a small vocabulary of signs ), then join us to get your fingers, hands, face and body moving, ASL-style!

IF you haven't taken an ASL class, or don't know the basics, don't be discouraged ... you can come along anyway and learn by watching, and gradually, participating. We have lots of resources that we can suggest for learning ASL from a qualified teacher or authentic source, such as books, online classes, and local classes at various locations near Boston.

If you can, "officially" RSVP, even if the RSVP is "No," so that we know who is definitely going to come.

It will be great to see folks!

Sean
results.how_to_find_us: We will be there signing our beautiful language to inspire all of you!

results.description:
Dear Boston Culture Lovers,

Let's enjoy the new Star Wars: The Force Awakens movie. 

Showtime is 5 pm at the AMC Loews Boston Common Theatres.


*** Meeting time for the group is ***4:15 pm*** sharp! *** at the door of the theater.  I will only know the theater number on the day of the showing. I will update the event comments with the exact theater number on the date of this event. 

Please plan to arrive at 4:15 pm at the door of the theater and congregate for 15 minutes as a group and then go into the theater at 4:30 pm. 

After the movie, if there is interest, we can go to a nearby restaurant.  It would be a great opportunity to socialize and discuss the movie.  I was thinking of Pho Pasteur in Chinatown, a short walk around the corner from the theater.  I am also open to other suggestions. 

I strongly recommend that you purchase your tickets in advance.  You may purchase your tickets online at https://www.amctheatres.com/movie-theatres/boston/amc-loews-boston-common-19 or your preferred online movie ticket vendor.  

It may be difficult for latecomers to connect with the group. If you are late, I can not guarantee that you will recognize me or fellow members or we to be able recognize you from the crowds. Once the event starts, I put away my smartphone.  Please plan ahead and allow a little extra travel time to this event.

Just a reminder, this is an actual meet-up event, not an advertisement. For events to be successful, I need to know who to expect and how many.  

This is a public event and you are certainly free to attend this event outside the Meetup group.  I just ask  that only reserve "YES" if you are definitely attending this event and intend to meet members of the group.  

If you reserve "YES", we will be expecting you.  If you reserve "YES" and then have a change of plans, please update the attendance reservation. A consistent history of not showing up for events may cause you to be removed from the group. 

This should be a fantastic event and look forward to seeing new and familiar faces. 

Joana

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball. 

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.

results.description:
Climbing MeetUp at MetroRock Gym in Everett. Toprope, sport leading, and bouldering available, including some tall walls up to 55 feet. Whether you're a new or experienced climber, join us for a fun and solid workout! We usually have people at all levels. Gym meetups are also a great way to make more friends for outdoor climbing. Plus Mondays are Ladies' Night: discounted admission. If you'd like to lead climb, don't forget to bring your rope :)

*** If you are new to MetroRock Gym and/or climbing, please see the FAQ below. ***

Please RSVP if possible; helps everyone to know others are coming.  Meet at the picnic table near bouldering area (usually the round one, furthest from the cubbies, if available) from 7 - 7:10 PM.  (NOTE: In the rare case the Event Host doesn't arrive within this time window, assume major traffic jam or other catastrophy, ask others nearby to find the group, make introductions, and go climb).  If arriving later, just come find us on the walls.  Hopefully you can recognize us, the Event Host(s) (see RSVP list), from our profile pictures, and/or check the small Whiteboard near the bathrooms and water fountain, for a description of what we're wearing that day.

Full-access Day Pass:  $22.  Students, Military or Bouldering-Only Pass:  $18.  Mondays are Ladies Night:  Women's Pass $14 after 3 PM & also special class pricing.

For membership, gear rentals, and other programs and pricing available, or for directions, check the gym website:  http://www.metrorock.com/

Frequently Asked Questions for Newbies:

Q) How do I get to the gym?

A) See website for directions: http://www.metrorock.com/ If you're driving here for the first time, it can be tricky to find MetroRock Everett, especially in the dark! Use a GPS if possible. MetroRock is in a building opposite Boston Coach.   If you don't have a vehicle, the gym offers a shuttle service from nearby Wellington T Station; call the gym for schedule details.

Q) I've never climbed at MetroRock Gym before, what do I need to do?

A) You'll need to take and pass a belay test for rope climbing. There is a separate test for toproping and sport lead climbing. For toproping, if you are not confident you can tie a re-threaded figure-8 knot and double fisherman's backup knot and safely belay a climber using an ATC device, it is highly recommended you take the Level 1 Safety class. They will not allow you to climb on ropes without passing a belay test. Call MetroRock in advance to reserve your spot in the class, and ask them about any discounts or special prices they are offering. Also, you can rent basic climbing gear (harness, shoes, belay device, etc), if needed, at the gym.

results.description:
(Please note: many of the friends who attend regularly are not Meetup members, so there are always more people attending that it says on the Meetup site.)

About This Meditation Meetup

We sit in silence for around 45 minutes, followed by discussion for around 30 minutes or so. The silent sitting is interspersed with some meditation instruction, perhaps a brief reading, a little simple inquiry, exploration or movement. Sitting posture is relaxed, either on a meditation cushion or a bench. It's not a rigid practice- move whenever you need to!

We meet every Monday night, 7:30 pm at the Cambridge Friends Meeting House. The Friends Meeting House is located at 5 Longfellow Park, Cambridge, MA 02138 You can find a very good map here: <a href="http://www.fmcquaker.org/FMC-Map_2006.pdf" target="_blank"></a>

http://fmcquaker.org/about-friends-meeting-at-cambridge/directions/

Parking is available after 6:00 in the loop off of Brattle St. that leads to the Friend's House, and there is a small lot in back of the Friend's House for those with limited mobility. After that, parking is a little tricky in Cambridge (lots of "resident only" signs), but you will find available parking on Mount Auburn St. near Friend's House and on Brattle St. as you head away from Harvard Square.

Coming by the T is a great option, with the Friend's House being a lovely 15 minute walk out of Harvard Square.

If you find you are running late, come anyway! The format is very relaxed and open— anyone interested in contemplative practice is welcome!

 

About Open Awareness Meditation Group

At the heart of these meditation sessions is the silent exploration of what we refer to as Open Awareness. We all know what it means to feel closed, limited, vulnerable, or separate. What is it like to allow ourselves to return to our natural condition of openness, presence, non-separateness and ease? This is what we explore in our meetings.

We have been meeting for over a decade, and those who lead the meditations have known each other and been practicing together for many years. They have all deeply explored a variety of traditions— for some it has been the Tibetan Buddhist practices of Dzogchen or Mahamudra, for others it has been the Indian traditions of Yoga, or Advaita, or what is currently referred to as Nonduality (some popular examples of this are Francis Lucille, Rupert Spira, Eckhart Tolle and Adyashanti). 

However all of these traditions ultimately point to the same truth, the truth of our basic awareness or presence which is beyond any tradition, practice or teaching. This is the presence we share, and the presence we are, beyond words. This is what we explore in our meetings.

This group is unique in that there is no specific guiding teacher, lama, or guru. We all meet as equals to question, share, and inspire each other to explore the Open Awareness we most deeply are. The meetings are suitable for newcomers as well as experienced meditators, and all are very welcome.
results.name: Open Awareness Meditation Group Meetup

results.description:
Save the time and date: Tuesday December 29, 2015, 12:30pm, somewhere in N. Cambridge.

Remember when you worked in an office,and they gave you some time to eat lunch in the cafeteria, and you actually pulled yourself away from your desk and went and ate lunch with other people? 

Nah, I don't remember that either, but it sure sounds like fun. And, it's the law. If your employer denied you a lunch break, you'd be filing a complaint with the state so fast. About 25 people expressed interest, which means that probably five to eight people will show up. 

The others will all have good excuses, such as, "It's too cold," "I'm too tired," "I have too much work," "I have a deadline," "my clients need me," etc. I don't want to hear your excuses, Please don't bore me with those lame-o excuses, I just want you to show up. 

RSVP by obtaining a free ticket at eventrbrite, first come, first served:

</a><a href="https://www.eventbrite.com/e/tuesday-collegial-lunch-for-people-who-work-at-home-in-arlingtonbelmontcambridge-tickets-20051476506">https://www.eventbrite.com/e/tuesday-collegial-lunch-for-people-who-work-at-home-in-arlingtonbelmontcambridge-tickets-20051476506 

that way I'll know you're coming, and be able to contact you easily. That will also help to limit the attendance. If you think this idea can fly, please do sign up and show up, and then we can repeat this pleasure again next week. bests,

-rsr-

Ron Rothenberg

4Buyers RE

[masked]

results.description:
Please RSVP! - Map and parking info at bottom of announcement.

Holiday Party/Meeting -

for both the IBD Meetup and the Boston Investors Group!

 Please bring food - main dishes, sandwiches, veggies, munchies desserts, drinks, cups, plates or ice! You may bring wine or champagne if you like. We will use the first hour of the meeting to celebrate the tenth anniversary. We will eat in the lounge area outside Room 335. Use the time to network, pick the brains of your fellow traders and introduce yourself to some of the members you haven't yet met. Please fill out a name tag and wear it. For the "serious" part of the meeting, we will have a talk by Mike Reis from Charles Schwab (see below).

I will be passing the hat (asking for contributions) at the meeting. My organizer dues amount to $240/year, and we have other organizational expenses.  Contributions didn't cover it last year and I haven't asked for any this year yet.  If you like what we do, if you've made money from what you've learned at the Boston IBD Meetup, please contribute.  If you'd rather contribute online, here is the link https://secure.meetup.com/BostonIBD/contribute/.  Thank you.  Enough said.

Practical Techniques for Profit Taking

By Mike Reis, Charles Schwab Corporation

One of the most difficult trading skills to master is knowing when to close out a trade and take profits.  In this workshop, we'll help you learn practical techniques for setting price targets and managing potentially winning trades to help maximize profits.

About Mike Reis:

Mike started his career in 1998 at the Chicago Board of Trade, trading Treasury bond futures. He spent the next 15+ years as an independent and proprietary trader. He has traded primarily Treasury, equity index and energy futures and options on futures, using a combination of technical, fundamental and quantitative analyses.  Then he was a senior Derivatives Trading Specialist with Options Express.  Currently, Mike is Schwab's Regional Manager of Trading Solutions.

Who We Are

This IBD Method is for people who are currently learning and applying IBD tools and the CANSLIM Method for trading leading growth stocks. 


Only those seeking to learn the IBD CANSLIM Method for trading leading growth stocks should attend.

These meetings are free of charge.

Here is a map link: http://whereis.mit.edu/?go=E51 

There is free parking in the lot next to the building and also one block West off Hayward St.
results.name: Holiday Party/Meetup

We start off chatting about our work, including setting goals for ourselves (which is entirely optional but super helpful!), and then we write. There is power for laptops, and some of us use pen and paper. Your choice! Bonus: there's no Internet access, so you can omit a huge distraction without even trying. And, although we are not a discussion group, there are many areas where people can go if they want to talk without being disruptive.

results.description:
CLOSED!

Why mess with a winning formula, right?


Let's get together AGAIN to finish out 2015 for a Meet and Greet at Viale, a new Mediterranean-inspired restaurant in Central Square, Cambridge followed by an optional dinner. We did it in October and had a good time. Why not again? can't think of a reason...

We'll start the evening with a Meet & Greet in the bar area of the restaurant. The RSVP fee includes tasting portions from 4 wines with assorted hors d'oeuvres and other nibbles, tax and tip included. I've since been back and Marc has added a few nice wines to his roster. Relaxed, informal wine and food tasting -- novice or expert, you will enjoy it. 

Afterwards about 8:30 PM, those who are interested can join us for a sit-down dinner. NOTE: $$ for dinner is NOT included in RSVP; the menu is very eclectic, covering several price points, so the choice is up to you. I ate there recently and expect the total tab to come to $25 (meet&greet) + $25 = $50 each.

COST

PRICE: $25 payable with your RSVP

Usual BostonWine refund policy applies. I will offer a full refund up to 24-hours prior to the event. Space is limited, so please don't RSVP unless you know that you can attend. RSVP fee is for Meet and Greet only--dinner is optional and extra cost.

POLICIES

Limited to 15 total including +1s. I may increase limit if there is enough interest. I may promote newbies up from wait list. Everyone must be a member of BostonWine and pay in advance. RSVP early, but please don't RSVP unless you're sure that you can make it.

NOTE: As part of the RSVP process you will be asked to accept the group's Policies and Disclaimer (use a new web browser window to see the About Us section of our group's home page). You must answer "Yes" in this event's RSVP to attend. (Note, apparently some versions of the Meetup mobile app don't display this question -- in that case, RSVP with your phone and then use a web browser later on to update your RSVP). 

WHAT TO BRING 

Yourself! Food and wine will be provided.

WHERE


Viale
502 Massachusetts Ave.
Cambridge, MA 02139
<a>http://www.</a>vialecambridge.com/

T: Red line, Central Square

Parking: Green Street Garage

Note about venue. Viale is a chic, urban restaurant at the MIT end of Central Square. Check it out at URL above. As with many urban neighborhoods, however, the square has its share of street people and rough edges, so put on your best city persona. I DO feel it is safe, however, and commute through it every day. Email me with questions.

ABOUT

Viale serves ingredient-driven, Mediterranean-inspired food in a warm and casual environment. The rotating menu showcases seasonal pasta dishes, appetizers, and entrees; simple grilled pizzas, and meats perfectly charred on a wood-fired grill. All major ingredients are locally sourced. The wine list features the vintages of small organic and biodynamic growers.

This promises to be a fun event. I look forward to seeing you!

-Jim
results.name: Meet and Greet AGAIN at Viale, Cambridge!

results.description:
"A universal theology is impossible, but a universal experience is not only possible but necessary. It is this experience toward which the course is directed." (ACIM Manual for Teachers)

Designed to correct perception and lead to a universal experience of knowledge, A Course In Miracles has been translated into 23 languages, is referenced and utilized by many of today's most reknowned spiritual teachers, and has inspired countless books and curriculums based on its teachings. But it can be a difficult book to grasp. It is lengthy, the writing is abstract, and its use of Christian terminology alienates many.

And yet it has become one of the most influential spiritual books of today. Join us as we dive into it, and are led to understand its principles against the backdrop of our own personal experiences and insights. Beginner as well as advanced Course students are welcome. We'll start with a short meditation, and then use a reading from the Course as an entry point into our time together. Cost $5 per person.

Bringing a copy of the book is helpful, but not necessary. Recommended (but again not necessary) is the combined volume that includes the three supplements (Clarification of Terms; Psychotherapy: Purpose, Process, and Practice; The Song of Prayer), available online from The Foundation For Inner Peace at acim.org.
results.how_to_find_us: From Concord St.: we're 4/10th's of a mile down Russell St. on the right, the driveway after Fraser Farm.
results.name: Join us as we discuss A Course In Miracles and apply its principles to our lives

This Meetup is intended for intermediate level players or higher, which means:Yankee C and above level, players with firm understanding of game strategy. Should be able to play 5-1 and 6-2 formations, have a good grasp of skills (passing, setting, hitting) and be able to move around to cover areas of the court. Play should consistently be bump-set-spike.



If you'd like to play, please do the following:


1. Send an email to Kory using the following URL: http://www.meetup.com/volleyball-122/message/?recipientId=8675200

2. In the message please indicate the date of event and your preferred position so we can make sure we have the right mix. ( If I don't know your position already)

Note that sending an email does not guarantee a spot to play; spots are only guaranteed if you receive a positive confirmation email. We will do our best to make sure the event is co-ed, have setters,  and incorporate a couple new members who want to join as well.

The location for this volleyball meetup is at the Orient Heights Community Center located at 86 Boardman Street in East Boston. Kory and Wing will be hosting these Tuesday night volleyball meetups.

This event is free if you are a member of Boston Community Centers. If not, it's a one-time $20 membership fee that is valid for a year. The Community Center is a short walk away from the Orient Heights T Stop on the Blue Line and also has plenty of parking. When you drive up, turn at the Mariott Hotel Sign and park in the lot or further along the fence.

As always, please remember:

- Respect the RSVP system (Don't show up expecting to play without a confirmed RSVP)

- The gym is open before the event to warm up, so please arrive a little early if you would like to warm up and stretch as we would like to start the game promptly from 7:00PM

- If it looks like you won't be able to make it or will run late please cancel your RSVP in time for someone else to join.  Event day/last minute cancellations and no shows will jeopardize your participation in future events.

results.description:
Ongoing class in Medieval and Renaissance Longsword in the tradition of Johannes Lichtenauer.

The Longsword is the iconic fantasy Knight's sword - a two-handed, straight blade with a cross guard. The weapon may seem to be simple at first but is in reality a weapon of finesse and skill.

The class covers all the basics of footwork, attacks and defenses. Drills are developed from simple to complex; from rigidly choreographed to open-ended. Timing, distance and judgement are developed. All classes begin with a Strength & Conditioning program designed to physically prepare one for fighting with the sword. Elements develop agility, core stability and power.
results.name: Lichtenauer Longsword

results.description:
Meditation practice gives us a chance to step away from the busy-ness of our day-to-day lives. It provides space for us to be free from reaction, from expectation, from doing, and step into the gentle space of being.

This weekly practice consists of 25-30 minutes of guided Vipassana meditation followed by a brief discussion. Vipassana meditation encourages us to experience each moment exactly how it is, fostering presence and awareness.

In this practice we allow thoughts, emotions, and all other stimuli to surface. We become a witness of these, cultivating a space of non-attachment and revealing a deeper connection with one's inner self.

Newcomers to meditation and long-time practitioners are welcome to attend. This is a FREE practice. There is a suggested donation, but that is not required to attend.

For magic potions, kids put water and anything from nature into a jar and mix it up, just like we did when we were kids. Making potions never gets old, and if done with some finesse, it helps kids develop creativity, imagination, sensory skills and several universal ways to encourage brain development known as behavioral schema. 

Register for this FREE event at https://tinkergarten.com/classes/639

(Because we are registering on an outside website, you won't be able to RSVP here on Meetup.)
results.name: Let's make potions!

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball. 

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.
results.name: Wednesday Lunchtime Soccer (OUTDOOR)
