results.description:
Ok, you're right. It is all about me. If you want to choose the exhibits, you can organize your own event.


Let's meet at 2:15 and browse some of the exhibitions at the MFA, and stroll through the galleries. at 3:00, we'll take the Arts of the Americas tours, that will last til 4:00 - the museum is open until 9:45 so you'll have a chance to see the exhibits you wish to see, also. Here's what I'd like to see:

Class Distinctions
Dutch Painting in the Age of Rembrandt and Vermeer

(I've seen this before, and it's definitely worth seeing again)

http://www.mfa.org/exhibitions/class-distinctions

Marilyn Arsem
100 Ways to Consider Time http://www.mfa.org/exhibitions/marilyn-arsem 

Gold and the Gods
Jewels of Ancient Nubia http://www.mfa.org/exhibitions/gold-and-gods I encourage you to support the museum, and buying a membership is an excellent way to do so -- you can get into all the Friday night social events, and also go to most other museum functions, and gain free admission any day the museum is open. What a bargain!! Some memberships start to pay for themselves after three admissions.

Regular adult admission is $25, but you may also be able to borrow passes from your local library.

Let's meet in the lobby, in front of the statue of Orpheus and Cerberus, and let's go see the exhibitions that I want to see. Of course, this is still a free country, pending the results of the election, and you can also look at some of the exhibitions you would like to see. I won't stop you.

results.description:
Hello ASL Enthusiasts!

A number of folks living NORTH of Boston have asked about an ASL SOCIAL. Let's make this happen!

On WEDNESDAYS, starting October 29 - 6pm to 8pm - I / we will be at the NORTH SHORE MALL Food Court.

While technology has improved the way people communicate, "Deaf Social Clubs" are slowly disappearing. This is a way to start bringing REAL social interaction back!

Please join us for a casual, relaxed, no-pressure two-hour Social, where we can chat, tell stories, get to know each other, and meet new people (or old friends!). Friends, Fun and Food!

A warm welcome is extended to all Deaf & non-Deaf people: folks in the Deaf Community, CODA's, Interpreters, ASL students, parents of deaf children AND their children, ASL professors/teachers, Relay Operators, Deaf services workers- EVERYONE!

This will be a "SOME ASL KNOWLEDGE and ABOVE" Social, because not all of us are ASL-fluent! "Voices- Off" -- we'll all laugh & learn WITH and FROM each other!

WHAT: ASL SOCIAL CLUB
WHERE: North Shore Mall Food Court, PEABODY,MA
DAY/TIME: Wednesdays, 6pm - 8pm
WHY: To meet like-minded people, socialize using ASL, tell stories, and have good time!
WHO: Anyone who wants to chat using American Sign Language!
HOW TO FIND US:  We'll be sitting on the couches closest to the "walkway" side of the Food Court, not hidden inside the food court, so easier to locate us!

If you have any question, please contact Connie or Paul I., through the EMAIL LINK via BOSTON ASL profile page.

PLEASE, if you would be good enough, RSVP either "YES" or "NO" so I know who to look for!

CHEERS!

Connie Cassidy / Paul I.

PEACE...
results.why: ASL is the third largest "foreign language" in the U.S.; ASL is fun to use; ASL is NOT English, but does "borrow" from the English language.
results.how_to_find_us: The folks talking with their hands!
results.name: Weekly North Shore ASL Social!

results.description:
To the left there is a chip-in feature. Your donations
will go directly to the monthly dues and will allow MAC meetup group to keep going. Any amount would be greatly appreciated. Thank you.

Come join us for a midweek climb!
All levels are welcome! If you are new to climbing, there is a belay class at 7 PM. Here is the link to sign up: www.centralrockgym.com/bookeo.php?s=watertown 

I will happily belay those who have not climbed before up until 7 PM, but then it's really important to know how to belay and to take the belay test that starts at 7 PM. You can rejoin the group after taking the belay test.

For those of you who already know how to belay, no need to take the class, you just need to pass this gym's belay test when you arrive.

The price is as follows:

Membership: $89/month

Adult Day Pass: $22 

Gear (shoes, harness, belay device): $8 ($5 for members)

Belay class: $15 (free for members)

Belay test: Free

We will meet at the cluster of cubbies on the first floor at 6:30 PM, greet each other, make sure everyone has a group or person to climb with then head off to climb. I'm looking into whether there is a place nearby to grab a bite or drink at the end of the night. If you have a place in mind, please let me know.

I'll send a message letting you know what color shirt and pants I am wearing incase you arrive late and want to search for us. I will also swing by the cubbies every 15 minutes until everyone who signed up has arrived. So, if you are not able to make it or are running late, PLEASE COMMUNICATE on this event's chat or by contacting my cell-phone, which I will send out once you are confirmed for the event.

Hope you can make it! I'm looking forward to meeting more climbers in the area.

~Avery~
results.how_to_find_us: Will meet at 6:30 PM at the cubbies by the stairs.
results.name: Climbing at Central Rock (Watertown)

results.description:
Come join David and friends for a night of Magic: The Gathering over at Not Your Average Joe's in Medford. This event is part of our "Wednesday Night Magic" series.

It doesn't matter if you are an expert "planeswalker", or don't know anything about Magic: The Gathering -- you can come to play or learn this amazing strategy game.  There are usually between 6-12 people at each event, consisting of all experience levels.  All decks of all types are welcome for this "casual play" event.  Beginners who want to learn are welcome!

This location is easily accessible from Rt. 16, Rt. 28 and Rt. 93, and is walking distance from the T, near the new Station Landing apartment complex. Here is a map of the area.

By Subway: Take the Orange Line to Wellington. Walk over the skybridge and cross through the parking lot. Upon exiting the garage, you'll see a building complex (SL75) across the street. Cross the street and take a right. Follow around this building and you'll find Not Your Average Joe's on the opposite side of the street.

By Car: If you are driving, be aware that Station Landing is at the intersection of Rt. 16 and Rt. 28, and you can enter the Station Landing complex from the north-bound side of Rt. 28, or the east-bound side of Rt. 16. There are a number of stores in the Station Landing complex -- look for the Margarita's, Starbucks or Not Your Average Joe's signs. NYAJ is located right off of Rte. 28. Although there is free parking all around the building, we recommend that MTG Boston members park in the garage underneath the restaurant.
results.name: Wednesday Magic In Medford Presents Popper Night

results.description:
Please come out and join us for a pleasant evening of competitive party bridge in  Newton Centre.  Wednesday night bridge here has been a multi-year Metrowest tradition; it is a nice quiet spot with a fireplace, good food, ample table space.  The more the merrier, so long as you know how to play bridge and love it.

This is officially canceled unless 5 players sign up by 5pm. We can still play with four if we re-confirm. Check this space at 5pm if quorum questions exist. Out of courtesy, please do not sign up casually, nor cancel out on the day of event except in emergencies.

You must know Contract Bridge rules and basic bidding to play this week. No formal training is to be offered, but this is a social, casual event. To assist novices, bidding advice and meanings will be openly discussed on any player's request.

ACBL Yellow Card is our group-standard bidding system; a novice should please take time to study all basic openings and responses shown above in yellow, plus standard Jacoby Transfer and Stayman responses to NT openings. We will expect a verbal alert on deviations an expert may make to these most-common conventions.
results.name: A Newton Center Bridge Party

results.description:
PLEASE NOTE: In anticipation of the Glass-Chewing Leader of the Cartel's imminent absence due to Family Growth, hosting duties for the regular Wednesday Night Gaming is being handled by a rotating cast of regulars.

Wednesday Night Gaming is our more-or-less weekly free-for-all of strategy gaming goodness downstairs at the Porter Square Panera. There's rarely a set agenda for these events but you are welcome and encouraged to hash out a plan beforehand in comments if you've got something you're dying to play. Nonetheless, you are not required to bring a game to play -- our only requirement is that you bring an open mind!

The event officially begins at 7 PM but people often trickle in early, so you're welcome to sit down to a filler game to get warmed up, or arrange to meet a little early if you've got a group looking to tackle an extra-meaty game.

Please be aware that Panera has been quite gracious about hosting us with minimal fuss -- in order to keep things this way, please respect the hardworking people who work there and, especially, their desire to get out after a long shift.

We'll see you at the gaming table!
results.name: Wednesday Gaming In Porter Square

results.description:
During the holidays, there is a good deal of talk about joy. If one observed our culture from the outside, it would appear that we believe this joy is attained through buying more stuff. I would imagine most of us reject this consumeristic pursuit of joy, at least in theory. But we are left asking:

- How do we attain or pursue joy? 

- How should we?

- How will your pursuit of joy be different in 2016?

- And is it possible to have a consistent sense of joy?

Hope to see you there!
results.how_to_find_us: We will be in the back two booths (behind the bar). Ask a hostess for help if you have any trouble locating us.
results.name: Joy in the New Year

results.description:
So what exactly is over the rainbow? Come to this healing and find out!

Ah, what a tease right? But maybe you're curious ... after all, we are always trying chase the rainbow, even though chasing it makes it disappear. So maybe that is the answer right off the bat ... stop chasing the rainbow, just appreciate it. But where is the drama in that you might say? Hehe, well that is the point on this side of the coin. But on the flip side, we journey through the colors and explore why life is worth shining your brightest!

results.description:
Join the Boston Austrian Economics group to kick-off our last meeting for the year, as we discuss the World Bank's ground breaking announcement about the record setting global poverty rate falling below 10%, all thanks to industrialization, and the BEAUTY OF CAPITALISM, for the first time in human history.

Please note that the readings are not required to attend our meeting, but are recommended. As always, anyone interested in economics is welcome.

Tony C's Sports Bar and Grill has plenty of parking and is accessible via the Orange Line "Assembly" stop. 

CHEERS TO THE FREE MARKET!

READINGS:

1) http://www.worldbank.org/en/news/press-release/2015/10/04/world-bank-forecasts-global-poverty-to-fall-below-10-for-first-time-major-hurdles-remain-in-goal-to-end-poverty-by-2030

2) http://www.worldbank.org/en/research/brief/policy-research-note-03-ending-extreme-poverty-and-sharing-prosperity-progress-and-policies

3) Complete PDF Report in English Available for Download: http://documents.worldbank.org/curated/en/2015/10/25114899/global-count-extreme-poor-2012-data-issues-methodology-initial-results

4) http://www.washingtonexaminer.com/amazing-chart-shows-thanks-to-capitalism-global-poverty-is-at-its-lowest-rate-in-history/article/2562224


QUESTIONS: 

1) What is the World Bank, and which two goals are they dedicated to achieving by 2030?

2) According to World Bank President Jim Yong Kim, which economic factors are responsible for reducing poverty?

3) Which three regions of the world account for 95% of the global poverty rate?

4) Since 1990, the World Bank claims global poverty rate has fallen by what percentage, and which two countries played a central role in this outcome?

5) Are all poor populations the same?

6) What is the poverty gap ratio?

7) Why is poverty a multifaceted phenomenon?

8) Which country has the highest rate of multidimensional poverty?

9) What does continued poverty reduction require?

10) What role does access to infrastructure have on the ability of the poor to generate income? 

11) According to Oxford University’s Institute for New Economic Thinking Fellow Max Roser, people have what to thank for the rapid decline in poverty?

12) The greatest decline of global poverty happened during which time period in world history?
results.name: THE WORLD BANK, INDUSTRIALIZATION, AND THE BEAUTY OF CAPITALISM

results.description:
Here are just some of the things you can get out of these meetings:

• Access to thousands of dollars of courses, software, and other resources

• Advice on overcoming a business or marketing obstacle you're facing

• Accountability

• Ideas and inspiration

• Meet awesome people who enjoy talking about this stuff as much as you do

Or, you can be a fly on the wall.  No pressure at all.  Feel free to drop in to just listen and see what internet marketing really looks like from people who are actually doing it.

We try to keep the meetings to about 60 - 90 minutes.  Here's the way it works:

• 7:00pm Join the meeting here:  https://hangouts.google.com/call/dq4qhhdefftaq3fmqwij2ipe2ea.  It tends to work best with Chrome (rather than Internet Explorer or FireFox).

• Intros, and goal checking:

• New Members:  What are you working on?  And what is it you hope to get out of attending these meetings?

• Existing Members:  How'd your week go?  Did you accomplish your goals?  What are your goals for next week.

• Check-Up on last week's Couch of Insight participate:  What results did he/she get from the session?

• The Couch of Insight:  One member goes into depth on what they've been working on, telling us where they need assistance, what resources have helped them to be successful, and what strategies have been valuable.

• (Meeting Ends around 8pm officially, but usually runs late with people wanting to help the person on The Couch.)

• Chat and Offer Assistance: The Hangout will remain open until everyone leaves.  You can stay as long as you want to meet new members and give the person on The Couch any advice or feedback you may have.

Feedback

What's ONE thing that would have made this meeting better? Either let me know during the session, or you can keep it anonymous by filling out the a Survey Monkey (I'll provide the link in the session).

<a href="https://www.surveymonkey.com/r/KFNMRFX"></a>
results.how_to_find_us: Google Hangouts.  Join by clicking the link in the description.  Give it a shot before the meeting to make sure you can join without any problems.  Let me know if you're having trouble.

results.description:
This is our brand new auxiliary meetup event.  This is a great opportunity to socialize and play games in a relaxed environment -- and best of all, there's no cap on attendance.

We are a casual group of people who enjoy playing complex board games -- the kind of board games that make you think. We play a variety of games, but the games at this particular event are going to be on the smaller side -- because those are often the games that work best in a cafe setting.

Our main meetup requires RSVPs due to heavy popularity and finite space.  This event runs simultaneously, two buildings away.  RSVPs are NOT required for this event.  RSVPs are still appreciated so the event hosts know how many people to expect, but you don't need to update them and can come even if you don't RSVP.

This event takes place once a week (alternating Mondays and Wednesdays), from 7:00 - 9:30 or 10.  Cosi closes at 10, but after 9:30, you are welcome to come and join the regular meetup at that point, no RSVP required.

Cosi Cafe has graciously allowed us to use their back seating area every week.  You are not required to buy anything from them, but their food is honestly pretty good, so please take advantage of them if you are hungry for dinner, soft drinks, or snacks.

We play whatever people bring, but you don't have to bring anything -- the hosts will always have a bag of games with them!  Some games that you might expect to see here include:

Red 7, Love Letter, Codenames, Pictomania, The Resistance, Avalon, One Night Ultimate Werewolf, Bang!, Glory to Rome, Innovation, Mottainai, Chrononaughts, Time Lines, Tash-Kalar

If you're looking for longer or larger Euros (like 7 Wonders, Puerto Rico, or Terra Mystica), check out our regular "Game Night" meetup.

If you haven't played these kind of games before, but think you'll like them, you're welcome too!  But be aware that you are NOT likely to find traditional American games (like Monopoly, Sorry, Risk, or Poker); heavy strategy or negotiation games (like 18xx, wargames, or Diplomacy); or pure abstract games (like Chess).

OUTBOUND (from Boston / from Park Street)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the front of the train. Cross the street. (If you take the escalator up, turn around first to see the street.) After crossing, turn left and walk about 20 feet to Cosi.

INBOUND (from Alewife / Porter / Harvard / Central)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the rear of the train. Take the stairs up, then up again towards the busy street, which is Main Street.  Turn left and walk about 20 feet to Cosi.

FROM BOSTON (or Memorial Drive) 
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading north (cross the river if coming from Boston).  Memorial Drive is the first cross street past the river; go past it. 
2) Take the first right, onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the first right after Memorial Drive.) 
3) Take the first right, onto Main St. 
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical.
5) One side of the parking lot has a bunch of buildings with a handicapped ramp leading into it.  Go up the ramp, through the walkway, and Cosi will be right next to you when you come out.

FROM CAMBRIDGE (or points west) 
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading south. 
2) Take a left onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the last left before Memorial Drive; there is a railroad crossing there.) 
3) Take the first right, onto Main St. 
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical.
5) One side of the parking lot has a bunch of buildings with a handicapped ramp leading into it.  Go up the ramp, through the walkway, and Cosi will be right next to you when you come out.
results.how_to_find_us: Steps from the Kendall Square Red Line, in the middle of the block.

results.description:
(Please note our new RSVP policy below.) 


We are a casual group of people who enjoy playing complex board games -- the kind of board games that make you think. We play a variety of games, most of which are Euro style games of medium complexity.  Games often last 90 minutes or more and involve juggling a lot of rules and factors in your head, to decide what to do.  However, there's also plenty of laughter and friendship involved.  If that sounds up your alley, we hope you'll join us. 

Our weekly meetup is in a TERRIFIC space for games steps from the Kendall Square T, with easy parking, and lots of room to spread out in.  Full directions are below.  The building door does get locked in the evening, but there is plenty of foot traffic in and out.  If you expect to arrive later than 8:30, send Tucker a message earlier in the day, and we'll make sure someone is there to let you in.

Our meetups happen once a week (alternating Mondays and Wednesdays), from 7:00 pm onwards.  Our group has been running since 2007, and we have a large crowd of regulars as well as new members each week.

1. Due to finite space, you must RSVP to attend.

2. Please be considerate of others -- only RSVP if you are likely to attend.  Likewise, If you need to cancel your RSVP, please do so at least 24 hours before the event.  This allows enough notice for someone else to use your spot.

3. Please save loud and/or big games (like those with real-time arguing) for after 9:30, when the room is less full.  This allows us to accommodate more people, and play a greater variety of games.

We play whatever people bring, which typically includes a lot of Euros.  Here's a "tip of the iceberg" look at a few games that have been popular lately:

7 Wonders, Terra Mystica, Race for the Galaxy, Splendor, One Night Werewolf, Le Havre, Hansa Teutonica, Machi Koro, Concordia, Super Big Boggle

As you can see, there is some real variety.  A few of our regular attendees bring about 20-30 games between them, so there's always a lot to choose from.  But if you have a game you like, just bring it with you!

If you haven't played these kind of games before, but think you'll like them, you're welcome too!  But be aware that you are NOT likely to find traditional American games (like Monopoly, Sorry, Risk, or Poker); heavy strategy or negotiation games (like 18xx, wargames, or Diplomacy); or pure abstract games (like Chess).

Finally, a note about Settlers of Catan, Carcassonne, and Ticket to Ride.  These are traditional "gateway games" that many people play when they first discover Euros.  Although you will occasionally find those games at our meetups, many of us have played them to death and have become more interested in games with a little more complexity to them.

OUTBOUND (from Boston / from Park Street)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the front of the train. Cross the street. (If you take the escalator up, turn around first to see the street.) After crossing, proceed behind the T entrance (perpendicular to Main Street).  Building E25 is the brick building a quarter block down, across from the parking lot.

INBOUND (from Alewife / Porter / Harvard / Central)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the rear of the train. Take the stairs or elevator straight up. Proceed straight ahead (perpendicular to Main Street). Building E25 is the brick building a quarter block down, across from the parking lot.

FROM BOSTON (or Memorial Drive)
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading north (cross the river if coming from Boston).  Memorial Drive is the first cross street past the river; go past it.
2) Take the first right, onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the first right after Memorial Drive.)
3) Take the first right, onto Main St.
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical. Exit the parking lot at the rear (opposite from where you entered). Building E25 will be directly across the street.

FROM CAMBRIDGE (or points west)
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading south.
2) Take a left onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the last left before Memorial Drive; there is a railroad crossing there.)
3) Take the first right, onto Main St.
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical. Exit the parking lot at the rear (opposite from where you entered). Building E25 will be directly across the street.

Once you enter, Room 119 is just past the stairs on the right. There is a suggested donation of $1.00 that goes towards site fees and party supplies.  (When we have a raffle, you will also receive an extra raffle ticket as thanks for donating.)

Feel free to email with any questions -- we hope to see you at a meetup soon.

OTHER POLICY DETAILS:

If you would like to come but there are no spots, consider attending our alternative "Light Game Night" a few steps away at Cosi Cafe.  You can also sign up as "wants a spot" and receive emails from meetup if a spot opens up.

We know everyone has emergencies.  But consistent, inconsiderate use of RSVPs -- which includes being a "no show", cancelling in the last 24 hours, or constantly cancelling RSVPs -- will lead to being removed from the group.  Sorry, we still like you, it's just not fair to everyone else!

If you use a "+1" spot, you are responsible for all of the above for your +1.  Since you are using two spots, it is extra important that you are considerate about it.

NEW MEMBERS: Welcome!  We look forward to meeting you.  If you want to bring a friend, please have them sign up with their own account rather than using a +1.  Unfortunately, we've gotten a lot of no-show +1's from first time attendees, so we don't accept those anymore.  Sorry!

results.description:
Join 50 to 80 or 100 dancers any Wednesday at Dance Freedom!!

We are the original barefoot weekly dance, continuously running for 44 years, that has spawned hundreds if not thousands of other dances around the world.

In a drug, alcohol, and shoe-free environment, we've been making friends and sharing safe and juicy dances for decades. Come join the fun!! Discover the joy of dancing in a totally non-judgmental atmosphere, where anything safe and respectful goes... dance by yourself, in a group, with a same or opposite sex partner, or even just chat and enjoy watching.

First time visitors are welcomed heartily, and get in for half price! Otherwise, you decide what to pay in a range from $10 to $20, or less later in the evening as the event nears its end (information on late admission discounts is at the door). Our friendly dancers range from utterly new at it to very skilled dancers in funk, rock, salsa, modern, jazz, hip-hop, African & Latin and swing, tango, contact improvisation, and our own unique spontaneous creations! Dance with or alongside amazing dancers from local dance troupes as well as with ordinary good-hearted rug cutters. At work they may be doctors, lawyers, programmers, massage therapists, expressive therapists, artists, students, dog walkers, scientists, or anything else, but at heart they all love to dance.

The music runs the gamut: funk, world music, soul & r&b, house, trance, hip-hop, salsa, yoga music, jazz or swing, reggae, disco, you name it! Each DJ from our rotating list has a unique style, but we try to include something for everyone in every set. We keep a good balance in the music: familiar with unusual, timeless with current, melodic with drum-based, and positive lyrics with instrumentals--in all kinds of rhythms & styles! In any given evening, the world music parts of our dance are likely to include at least 3 or so of the following... African, Latin, Indian, Middle Eastern, Caribbean, zydeco, gypsy and much more. You'll hear everything from basic party music to very danceable songs with socially conscious lyrics, but you won't be hearing anything sexist, racist, violent, hating or otherwise divisive.

Start with a soothing stretch and warm up at 7:30, connect with the group and start to boogie at 7:50 with our first DJ of the evening, take a brief break at 8:50 for community announcements and a short unique performance or workshop (or chatting & stretching in a way that doesn't interfere), then cut the rug again by 9:15 at the latest with the evening's second DJ, till 10:30--plenty of time for a great workout and some feel-good inspiration and respiration and perspiration!

At the beginning of each half of the evening's music, everyone who wants to gathers around a centerpiece to hold hands, and dance in a winding chain together to a song with uplifting, connective (or at least beautiful and hypnotic) slow to medium tempo rhythms. (This dance was created from out of a drumming circle on the Cambridge Common in the sixties, after all, and some of that great political and community spirit still lives on here.) Then, it's all dance music, generally building in tempo to a crescendo, slowing down again for some more melodic and slow dance songs for a few minutes, then gradually building to a second crescendo. The second half of the evening's dance follows roughly the same pattern with a different DJ and style, and ends with another circle dance for those who enjoy it.

Dancers are always welcome to help with set-up or take-down, and get in free for doing so! It's a great chance to get to know the community better and be serviceful, as well as to save money and help us to be around for another 42 years... Welcome! For more information, E-mail: [masked]

results.description:
Ellen Jaffe JonesThe Veg Coach

Creative Cook / Author / Consultant
From our test kitchen to your home kitchen

OK, show of hands.  How many of you eat quinoa as a side dish?
Most cooks use the protein-rich grain as a substitute for rice.
But, I've got a treat for you today.  It's a recipe for Quinoa crisp chocolate balls!
What a way to reward yourself for following a healthy lifestyle.

Find it below.

Consider this too as a tasty approach to getting people interested in coming to one of my FREE cooking classes. This week, Wednesday at 9pm EST, I'll be doing a free class prepping and serving 2 recipes from my book "Eat Vegan on $4 a Day." Bring any questions to our Google Hangout: 

https://plus.google.com/events/c0oegddjuh07utbrq1mv6vm1rfg

Happy cooking,

Ellen Jaffe Jones
The Veg Coach
http://www.vegcoach.com

Buy my books:

Paleo Vegan

Eat Vegan on $4 a Day

Kitchen Divided - Vegan Recipes for Semi-Vegan Households

This is a Quinoa crisp chocolate bar you might find at your local health food store.  
But, my recipe lets you create your own Quinoa chocolate treat.  

It'll satisfy your chocolate cravings and it's so easy to make.  

The recipe is below.

You're Going to Love This!  

Quinoa Crisp Chocolate Treats
by Ellen Jaffe Jones

INGREDIENTS 

1 cup vegan chocolate chips
1/2 cup puffed quinoa
4 teaspoons coconut oil
1/8 teaspoon salt (optional)

PREPARATION INSTRUCTIONS

1 cup vegan chocolate chips
1/2 cup puffed quinoa
4 teaspoons coconut oil
1/8 teaspoon salt (optional)

Melt chocolate chips in a double-boiler, or place in a microwave-safe bowl and heat for about 60 seconds until the chips develop a slight sheen.  
Place all ingredients in a medium pot (or add to the double-boiler) and over medium heat, and stir constantly for about 5 minutes taking care not to burn the chocolate. 
Form small balls and place on a non-stick cookie sheet.  
Refrigerate for at least 60 minutes before serving.  
For those wanting to reduce fat intake, this can be made without the coconut oil, but make sure the chocolate chips are completely melted.

Grab a whole day of instruction for yourself at a bargain rate. 

You can take advantage of a full day of one to one instruction with Ian 9am to 5pm for just $300'  or you can split the time into two half days, or even choose an afternoon and and an evening. What is more, if you like you can bring up to  three friends and make it your own private workshop to be held on a day that is convenient to both you and Ian ( be aware that there are limited weekend openings and that weekdays provide a greater chance of finding a time). 

If you move quickly you could even book all five days and have your own  week- long workshop for just $1500 or even spread the days across a number of months..  The opportunity is there for you to grab it.

You can book it now and use it any time in  2015. Book an outdoor or indoor day or a mix of both and have it happen in the spring, summer or fall.  The choice is yours.

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball. 

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.
results.name: Thursday Lunchtime Soccer (OUTDOOR)

results.description:
What can you do for entertainment? While you're waiting for the ball to drop, play games! You can play a round of cards or trivia, partake in friendly competition with a board game or get a bunch of folks to play Wizard.

Cards Against Humanity always makes for a fun time (most of the cards aren't PC – you've been warned!). Telastrations After Dark is another fun way to bring everyone together. I guarantee you'll make some fun memories from these games that you can carry over to the New Year.

Join the C&C crew over at Not Your Average Joe's in Medford for a special New Year's Eve edition of fun and games. Ring out 2015 enjoying some afternoon board games, card games or party games (or just want to meet people!), before hitting the New Years party.

Please note: I've set this meet up to end at 6pm - if the restaurant is open later and people want to stay and they aren't looking for our space we can stay longer for those who would like too.

HOW TO GET THERE

This location is easily accessible from Rt. 16, Rt. 28 and Rt. 93, and is walking distance from the T, near the new Station Landing apartment complex.

By Subway: Take the Orange Line to Wellington. Walk over the skybridge and cross through the parking lot. Upon exiting the garage, you'll see a building complex (SL75) across the street. Cross the street and take a right. Follow around this building and you'll find Not Your Average Joe's on the opposite side of the street.

By Car: If you are driving, be aware that Station Landing is at the intersection of Rt. 16 and Rt. 28, and you can enter the Station Landing complex from the north-bound side of Rt. 28, or the east-bound side of Rt. 16. There are a number of stores in the Station Landing complex -- look for the Margarita's, Starbucks or Not Your Average Joe's signs. NYAJ is located right off of Rte. 28. Although there is free parking all around the building, we recommend that C&C members park in the garage underneath the restaurant

results.description:
Every Thursday evening at 6:30 PM we gather as a group for a nice nighttime "romp" at the Chestnut Hill Reservoir. It's a great way to wind down a busy work day, to catch up with Bulldogs friends, or to meet new people!

The Boston Bulldogs is a co-ed non-profit running club founded to support those battling addiction and in recovery, those who have been affected by addiction and their supporters.

We welcome and encourage runners of all levels – dreamers, beginners, as well as those with running experience, past or present. Our volunteer runners will be there to coach you at your current level, and help you meet your goals. We might even be able to help with running gear if needed. 

We meet twice weekly at the Reservoir (Cleveland Circle/Reservoir Green Line C or D train) -- on Saturday mornings at 10:00 am and Thursday evenings at 6:30 pm. We will first gather in front of the Starbucks in Cleveland Circle, before heading over to the reservoir. See you there! 

If you are interested in becoming a member or a volunteer, in making a contribution to the Club, in sponsoring a runner in recovery, or in learning more about the Boston Bulldog educational wellness/running program, contact us at:

• Website - BostonBulldogsRunning.com

• Email - [masked] 

• Phone -[masked]
results.how_to_find_us: We will start gathering outside the Cleveland Circle Starbucks at around 6:15pm... see you then!

We'll run routes along the Charles River Greenway, Riverwalk, Newton and neighborhoods of Waltham, with options to extend for those who are looking to add distance (or end early!) Afterward we'll hop into the bar for post-run drinks. 

We meet in front of Shoppers Cafe and leave at 7:00p. There should be plenty of parking on the street and in the neighborhood. All levels are welcome, with a broad range of paces!

Runs are typically 3-5 miles. 

As our daylight becomes more limited, it is highly recommended to at least wear bright clothing, and also to consider bringing a reflective vest and/or lamp.  


See you there!

A new year and a new season of snow! 

Join the Makusues for NYE, get some nice turns in at Wildcat, Attitash or travel a little further to other mountains in the area. 

- The cost will depend on your length of stay and may be adjusted after meal confirmation-


Arrive NYE and stay one night - $62 (Includes dinner and breakfast)


Arrive NYE and stay through the weekend - $200 (3 nights stay, 3 social events, meals)


Enjoy skiing on the 1st, we will coordinate the best mountain to go to.


Play hooky on Friday and stay for the whole weekend! We have events planned on Saturday and plenty of skiing and riding to do!


Remember to bring

Bedding, Pillows, Towels, Toiletries, Gear for you chosen activity, Lunch for all days.

I will follow up all yes RSVPs with an email and a phone call to all first time visitors.

This is always a fun weekend and a great chance to get to know the Makusues!

results.description:
We will have our second annual New Year's Eve photo shoot at Jürgen's home. That location has a large backyard and the Charles River. We plan on doing light painting, shooting star trails, if cloud cover permits and if temperatures are decent, we may include floating lights on the water (fished out for re-use by volunteers). If weather turns out to be sour, the family and guest rooms will be our light painting studios.


We will have food and drinks available and plan on a midnight toast to welcome 2016. Instead of fireworks, as is custom in Germany, we will do our own light painting bursts. Please bring light painting paraphernalia, but we will also have a lot onsite.


Space is limited and we need to plan ahead for food and drinks. Please RSVP only if you know that you can attend. Feel free to bring you better half, but no children, please.


Bring tripod, camera, intervalometer and lenses (wider range), light painting gadgets and dress in layers, bring boots if it has snowed. More than one foot of snow will be prohibitive.


The river is right behind the ring of fire:

The playground (east to west, and all of the above in that space):

Front yard:

(the leaves are gone).


Wooded area between front and back:
results.name: 2nd annual New Year's Photo Shoot

results.description:
New Year's Eve at CIMC with Nancy Riemer and Larry Peltz. On this last evening of the year, join the Cambridge Insight Meditation Center for an evening of reflection, intention, relinquishing, inspiration, poetry, suttas, discussion, dharma, sitting, walking and song. Light refreshments will be served after midnight. You are welcome to attend all or any part of the evening. There will be a flow to the evening which will guide and pace it. No registration required.

Please feel free to bring a favorite poem or reading or song to share. As the evening unfolds, our schedule may be adjusted.   

7:30pm Introductions, Reflections and Setting Intentions
8:00pm Sitting meditation
8:30pm Walking meditation
8:45pm Reflecting on our intentions with others
9:00pm Break
9:15pm Dharma Talk: Habits and the Four Great Efforts
10:00pm Sitting meditation
10:30pm Break
10:45pm Sitting meditation and metta practice
11:15pm Walking meditation
11:30pm Sharing of poems, readings, songs, reflections
12:00am Welcoming the new year, metta blessings
12:00am Refreshments and conversation
1:00am Center closes

Nancy Riemer, LICSW has a longstanding meditation practice. She utilizes mindfulness in her psychotherapy practice and teaching. Her work has focused on trauma recovery, clinical hypnosis, creativity and spiritual development. Larry Peltz, MD is a psychiatrist specializing in mindfulness and addictions. He is the medical director of the Bournewood-Caulfield Partial Hospitalization Program, which integrates mindfulness into the recovery program. He is the author of The Mindful Path to Addiction Recovery: A Practical Guide to Regaining Control over Your Life (Shambhala 2013). He has a longstanding meditation practice.

Note from Anna: I believe this is a free or by donation event. For more information, please visit <a>www.cambridgeinsight.org</a>

<a></a>
results.how_to_find_us: There will be someone at the door directing people, the meditation hall is on the top floor

Although the format of the evening is largely Buddhist we try to make it as non denominational as possible. To attend, or for more information please call[masked]-6156.

results.description:
Hi all. Reservations made (via cc), for fourteen (Underground advance guard), of us in the main dining room. There are no details yet, we are the first in. The cost each will be $37.50 per.  The manager will call me with details, once she talks to the owner, and chef. If interested in joining us please call (978)[masked] ASAP, and tell her you are with NSS.  You will be seated either at smaller tables (2-4) with us, or upstairs to eat. She vowed to try to keep us all together. The sooner that the individual reservations are made, the greater the likelihood of us all being together.  The customary courtesy bus service will be derailed, in observance of this anticipated memorable night, please plan accordingly. Mystic River Band will guide, and groove us into trip to what will be. Ed is a a local Medfaar boy, and loved our previous interaction. Our first logged request will be: New Order - The Perfect Kiss 1985. It was symbolic meaning, surprise. 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=x3XW6NLILqo


 http://www.themystics.net/

As a side note Only sign up if you intend to go. You will NOT be sitting at our main table but the manager vowed to keep us NSS together. Do not hold a spot until something better comes along for NYE.  The Buffet will be amazing as will the music. And you can't beat the price.  Make your smaller tables in two to four people by calling Jules directly and tell them you are with NSS and you MUST hold reservation with a Credit Card DIRECTLY WITH JULES BY THE WATER. We will not be collecting money from those that sign up. Do NOT sign up and hold a spot until this is done please. Thank you in advance and looking forward to spending NYE with fabulous friends.

results.description:
Looking for something fun this New Year’s Eve? Boston Swing Central is hosting our 7th Annual, New Year’s Eve Vintage Ball at the Arlington Town Hall. For those of you fretting over New Years plans, worry no more!

The Dan Gabel & the Abeltones Dectet is our entertainment for the evening and we can barely contain our excitement! A 10-piece big band featuring the wonderful vocals of Elise Roth!

What is Boston Swing Central’s New Year’s Eve Vintage Ball?…a swing dance party harking back to the lively 20’s, 30’s and 40’s! Vintage black tie dress-up encouraged (but not required). You can count on a fun packed night of dancing which includes:

Dan Gabel & the Abeltones Dectet

Midnight Sparkling Cider Toast

and more…

When: Dec 31, 2015, 8-9pm Swing lesson, General dancing from 9pm to 12:20am

A special deal of "Pay-What-You-Can (within reason)" is effect until Dec 15th. Yes, you set the price, with a minimum of $18. See bostonswingcentra.org/newyears to get your tickets today.

Where: Arlington Town Hall, 730 Mass Ave, Arlington, MA 02476
results.name: New Year's Eve Vintage Ball at the Arlington Town Hall

John and I would like you to join us to celebrate and ring in the New Year!!!

2015 has been a great year and I am excited to see what 2016 will bring. 

2015 has been a  year of new friendships, new adventures and an amazing new relationship with John, who I met through Meetup a few years ago.  What better way to celebrate, than with our Meetup family.

We will have plenty of decorations, party goods & champagne on hand. All we ask is that everyone brings something to share.  Whether it's soda, wine, dessert, appetizer, snack food, pizza, take out.............whatever you would like to bring would be GREAT!  Just post a comment with what you plan to bring :-)

Our house is big and we have extra bedrooms and plenty of floor space, so people are welcome to pack their jammies, pillow and blanket and stay overnight.   We live in New England, so you never knows what the weather will be like.

Enjoy the rest of 2015!

Norma & John

results.description:
2016 New Years Eve Masquerade Ball
"Definition Of Masquerade Ball:

A: A Social Gathering Of Persons Wearing Masks And Often Fantastic Costumes

B: A Costume For Wear At Such A Gathering
2 : An Action Or Appearance That Is Mere Disguise Or Show

This event is in a fabulous space at Lulu's Allston at 421 Cambridge Street. The perfect upscale loungy venu for the occasion. 

Masks are encouraged but optional. Dress to impress…no sneakers, no caps! Valid ID required, 21+ event! Come dance the night away!! 

Event Features
- Party starts at 9pm goes on until 2am
- NYE Party favors & decor
-Live Ball Drop at Midnight on the Multiple TV's
- Champagne Toast at Midnight
- Dj Big will be Rocking the Dance Floor with Top 40/ Hip Hop/Mashups/ Intl / Latin mixes
- Limited Masquerades will be provided
- A Fun Venue with a fun staff
- Limited Tables available for reservation (Includes a bottle of Champagne)
- Plenty of Street Parking At Lulu's Allston. Will sell out. 

Get your tickets quick or visit http://www.Highrollerboston.com for more info

results.description:
pera, etc. Ring in the New Year with The Love Dogs in beautiful Powers Hall in Town Hall. Voted “Best New England Band” by Blues Audience magazine, The Love Dogs have been Boston’s favorite blues band for almost 20 years, and they’re still blowing strong. They combine elements of jump blues, New Orleans R&B, and good ol’ rock n’ roll into their own powerhouse sound. With their red-hot horn section, boogie-woogie piano, and stinging Fender guitar, you won’t be able to stay in your seat!
9:30pm-12:30am
AGE 21+ ONLY.
$20 through Dec. 26th
$25 after Dec. 26 and at the door.
Cash bar and light refreshments provided.
You and your friends and family will swing and boogie into 2016! Don’t miss it!

$20.00 Advanced purchase required, at Town Hall or online: http://www.newyearsneedham.org/countdown-party/

Also:

Interjecting uproarious comedy into each program, Jon creates a hilarious and unique presentation that never fails to blow the audience away. Stetson blends the art of Mystery with the study of Psychology, the predictability of human nature and the power of intuition, with a disarming sense of humor. The result is slack jawed amazement, where the most skeptical of audience members begin to feel a renewed sense of wonder as impossibilities become realities.
Jon Stetson’s engaging programs are packed with audience participation. Imaginations are wowed, stretched and captured, as thoughts are revealed and minds are being read, with Jon’s intriguing games of mind to mind contact.
Along with hundreds of corporate appearances, Jon has performed for three U.S. Presidents, The King of Sweden, The Royal Family of Monaco, and has appeared on several major Television Networks.

no ticket required. Check out New Year's Needham for a whole day of interesting events for you, your friends and your family.

results.name: Cheers!!!! To 2016

results.description:
**Get Early Bird Tickets here:  http://goo.gl/jIjzK5

The ADAM RISING PARTY is the most inspired party in Boston this New Year’s Eve and the ultimate destination for agents of change!

This party is for you if:


* you are a seeker, a creative thinker, an artist, poet or a musician


* you care about the world and you want to be a part of changing it


* you want to have ecstatic and meaningful experiences meeting other like-minded people 

ADAM RISING is a place for you to celebrate, to play, to dance, to grow, and experience new dimensions of oneness with the most progressive people from all over.

Unlike other parties where you listen to music and dance but have no idea what else to do, this party is specifically designed to facilitate conscious and creative interactions throughout the night. 

Our bands and music are curated especially to support you in going deep into your journey through consciousness, and taking you to above and beyond your own inner heights.

ADAM RISING is your chance to reflect upon the previous year, set intentions for yourself and for others, and begin to rise above into the year 2016.

ADAM RISING is also a space for your five senses to be nourished, healed and rejuvenated. Enter our Healing Sanctuary for a chance to experience Tantra, Reiki, and other Energy practices. Join us for our Raw Cacao Ceremony and Tsog Sensual Feast to enhance your energetic field throughout the night.. Join us this New Years Eve for a night like no other!

:::: Welcome to THE ADAM RISING 2016 Experience! ::::

*~*~* Interactive Mandala Theater by Anima Mundi and Luba Evans

*~*~* Incus Band Keynote Performance with Jason Cohen

*~*~* Shir David, Tribal Jewish music

*~*~* Healing Arts Sanctuary with the Healers

*~*~* Tibetan Tsog: Sensual Feast (optional)

*~*~* Raw Cacao Tantric Ceremony with Luba Evans (optional)

*~*~* Bliss Body Belly Dance w/ Kalidasi Burgress

*~*~* Best DJs of New York and Boston Area

*~*~* And more

:::: THE ADAM RISING Music Line Up ::::

Incus ::: House, PsyTrance, Balkan, and World Music DJs ::: yAshAkAshA :::: DJ MAASHA ::: More coming soon.


Here is a preview of some of the sound vibration going down: 


Incus 

www.facebook.com/MusicShapedByFire


:::: Interactive Mandala Theater by Anima Mundi and Luba Evans ::::

Experience the story of the evolution of human and universal consciousness through the eyes of Adam Kadmon: the original man. Through interactive theater and human mandalas, try on exciting roles within the story of creation, discovering what it would be like to be or to fall in love with a plant, an animal, an alien, a cyborg, a hologram or even … a human!

:::: Evolution Costume Party ::::

Costumes are highly encouraged. Come dressed as the Past or Future of Evolution, or take inspiration from one of the characters of our Interactive Theater featured on the poster. Best costume wins a $100 Amazon gift certificate at the end of the night!

:::: Raw Cacao Ceremony ::::

All are welcome to join in this delicious opening ceremony that nourishes and liberates the mind, body, and soul. 


As we drink the raw cacao, we remind our bodies that they are liquid and our minds that they are cosmic; through the chocolate fueling our connectivity, we expand our hearts and cultivate a deeper unconditional love and acceptance for all.

:::: Tibetan Tsog: Sensual Feast ::::

"Tibetan Tsog" is also referred to as the gathering of ‘delightful substances.’ In Tibetan Buddhism, this abundant sensual feast is offered to chosen practitioners to celebrate the most luxurious and extravagant things life has to offer. The food and drink are specifically chosen to intoxicate you with their richness and ambrosiac qualities of Bachus. Though the feast starts at 9PM, it is ongoing throughout the night.

** Get Tickets here! 

http://goo.gl/jIjzK5

WHAT PEOPLE ARE SAYING ABOUT OUR EVENTS:

"Insightful, invigorating, intoxicating and liberating are just a few of the words I feel" ~Marc I

"I felt really amazing coming into this space, this environment. I feel like they really provided and environemtn where can really be themselves. People are really going to have a powerful and healing experience at these events. I am just so excited to be bringing this to a wider audience here in the city. In the heart of it all.” ~Ella

"Transforming and Yummy!" ~Maryanne Savino

"It was a beautiful event with lots of interactive exercises designed to raise energy, as well as live music and dancing. Luba and her crew are wonderful! They created a loving and safe environment. It was very festive." ~Complexcarb

"All I could say is WOW" ~Violetta

"Magical, giving, safe space to find and be your best self. Luba opened our hearts to the beauty in ourselves and others and energized the whole group in a way that created an inner peace, which sounds contradictory. You have to experience it. She has a pure heart that radiates love." ~Michael

"Exceeded all my expectations" ~Alex R

WEBSITE/VIDEO:


http://www.mandalaparty.com/

CONTACT:


For Questions, or Volunteering Information, contact Alice at [masked].

Get Tickets Here: 

http://goo.gl/jIjzK5

results.description:
Rock in the New Year on a WARM (weather forecast 45 degrees) vessel cruising Boston's magnificent Harbor! Take in the extraordinary beauty of Boston's world class skyline, as you depart shoreside nonsense for a deLIGHTful sea journey.

Aboard a Massachusetts Bay Lines vessel, you can expect a dance-dynamite DJ for shaking your booty, a well stocked cash bar, colorful noise makers, delicious crackers and cheese, AND of course, a CHAMPAGNE toast at midnight all included in the $55 fee. 

On this popular 3 hour New Year's Eve Cruise, you will get to view the midnight fireworks (weather permitting) while toasting old friends and new. Come on down to the elegant Rowes Wharf in your nautical BEST and celebrate the dawn of 2016 in style. Dress code is smart, NYE classic. Adults only (21+). Boarding begins at 9:15 pm. Cruise 10pm-1am

See you there!
Tickets at https://www.eventbrite.com/e/new-years-eve-fireworks-cruise-tickets-19480646137?aff=ebrowse or

https://www.zerve.com/MassBayLines/AdultNYE

results.description:
As it's the Holiday Season once  again, here is your opportunity save 40%


After much pressure from members I have relented and decided to offer the usual annual discount offer again.

you can save 40% off the regular workshop price by pre-paying now  for next year's  upcoming workshops.  This offer will end on Dec 31st.

Please note that the discount can't be applied to workshops and events that take place outside of the USA nor can it be applied to workshops organized on behalf of third parties such as  Hunts Camera,  or other third parties where payment is generally made directly to them.

Sign up for the discount and give it as a gift for the holidays. You can transfer the credit to anyone.

HOW IT WORKS

Pay only $30 for each $50 credit towards future workshops - that's a massive 40% saving!

e.g. Pay only $60 for  $100 of workshop classes.

Pay only $120 for $200 of workshop classes.

Pay $300 and get $500 of workshop credit

Get a massive $1000 worth of classes for just $600

That's $50 of workshop credit for each $30 you pay before Jan 1st.

Want to give generously to your friends and family? then pre-pay for a workshop at the discounted rate and save yourself  40%.  (Gift Certificates can be supplied)

Want to improve your skills in the new year - then treat yourself to any number of future workshops at 40% discount by pre-paying before Jan 1

With over 380 workshops already offered  and an average offering of over 120 per year,  you know there is going to be something for everyone in the new year.

To pre-pay just RSVP as follows:

For a single $50 value just RSVP for yourself and pay the $30

For two $100 of credit RSVP for yourself plus 1 guest and pay the $60

For $200  of credit RSVP for yourself plus 4 guests and pay $120

For $500 of  credit RSVP for yourself plus 9  guests. and pay just $300

For $1000 of Credit RSVP for yourself and 19 guests and pay just $600

You can add as many guests as you like for thirty dollars each,  and for each one you add you get $50 of credit towards next years classes and beyond.

Of course the guests are virtual - the total amount of credit is yours and yours alone. - it's the way we need to RSVP to allow Paypal to accept the correct amount of dollars for the number of $50 credits you wish to purchase at the $30 price.

There is no limit to the number of credits you can purchase at this massively reduced rate. But don't delay - this pricing is only available for a limited time.

HOW TO USE YOUR CREDIT

Pre-pays can be used throughout 2014 and beyond (they don't expire) Just email Ian ([masked]) with a request to be added to the workshop of your choice and if there is space available you will be all set.

If you purchased credits last year or in the past  and haven't quite managed to use them - don't worry they don't expire. You can use them anytime.

Note that credits purchased are not refundable and the normal no refunds, credits or rain checks policy applies to any workshop to whcih you apply them.

If you have any questions just email Ian at [masked] or call hom on[masked]
results.name: HUGE 40% Workshop Discount is back.

results.description:
Please note: This "event" is not happening in any physical location.  I am posting this notice about our Jan/Feb calendar so that you can all see an overview of what is upcoming and add Mindful Boston to your schedule.  

After the holidays, it will be time to dig more deeply into learning meditation skills.  So make some space in your calendar to meditate with us!  8)


January 2016 
New Year's resolution: attend free Community Nights! 
Mindful Boston is offering three weeknight free events during the month of January.  

• Wednesday 1/13/16 LovingKindness w/ Rick 

• Wednesday 1/20/16 Seated Awareness w/ Valerie 

• Wednesday 1/27/16  Being Aware of Being Loved w/Susan


February 2016
• Eating Chocolate Mindfully: a new class planned for Valentine's day.


•Meditation Toolbox 
The Meditation Toolbox is tentatively scheduled for Sunday afternoons starting on Feb 21st. It will be six Sundays. Registration is not yet open. We will make sure to post registration details for the Toolbox during January so that you have at least 30 days to register ahead of time. 

April 2016
In early April, the Toolbox class will end, and the MBSR Intensive will start immediately. It will be 9 Sunday afternoons.
If you want to take Mindful Boston's MBSR, you must be a graduate of our Toolbox class. So make sure to attend the February Toolbox if you have not yet attended one of our previous Toolbox classes.

Bringing Mindful Boston teachers into your organization 
Mindful Boston will be growing our workplace program offerings during 2016.  If you are interested in bringing a meditation teacher into your location, visit our webpage at http://www.mindfulboston.com/workplace/
results.name: MindfulBoston's tentative 2016 class schedule

results.description:
Start the year of right with a morning hike through Bradley Palmer State Park!

Enjoy a guided outdoor hike starting at DCR headquarters and ending at Willowdale Estate with coffee, hot cocoa and our famous cookies! Hikes of two distances will be offered.

Two hikes are offered – one about 1 mile which will take you through natural, historical and cultural time at the Bradley Palmer Estate. The other – 2 miles, goes through the park and up over Moon Hill. Both conclude at the renovated Willowdale Estate, where the Directors will open their doors for a public tour of Bradley Palmer’s mansion, complete with refreshments.

Please dress in layers for the weather, hats, gloves and wear winter boots.  For more information or in the case of inclement weather, call[masked] or visit www.mass.gov/dcr/events.  Pre-registration is not required but is helpful to estimate our needs for refreshments.

t's going to be a beautiful day, here's the guaranteed cure for your cabin fever. We'll walk about 2 miles at Mt. Auburn, then each circuit of Fresh Pond is about 2.25 miles.

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball.

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.

YOUR DREAMS AND INTENTIONS

How will you start your new year?

plus tax and tip.

*** Advance purchase needed at http://bvsdinner.brownpapertickets.com

Note: We will have our beautiful festival organic cotton totes, 15"h x 18"w x 6"d, for sale for $5 cash.                           

NEW YEAR'S DAY DINNERS (2 seatings)

Friday, January 1, 2016
12:30 pm and 3 pm 
Grasshopper (an all vegan restaurant)
1 North Beacon Street
Union Square in Allston (part of Boston), MA 02134

<a>[masked]</a>

(See Directions at bottom.) 

We will be served "family style" at friendly tables of 8, so don't hesitate to arrive alone! 

As tables of 8 fill up, they will be served. (This is not a buffet.) 

$14.25 per person plus tax (7% in Boston) and 15% tip = $17.50 
Children:6 - 12 years old are "a little above half" price ($8.75) 
5 years and under are free 

ALL ARE WELCOME - Your friends and family are invited!  

MENU 
*  No animal Ingredients  *
All included  
Vietnamese Salad  -- finely shredded raw cabbage, carrots, daikon, and celery with tofu, in a light sweet/sour dressing, topped with chopped peanuts (served on the side) 
Nori Rolls - Sticky rice with shredded carrot and daicon, avocado, wrapped in thin paper of sea vegetable, with pickled ginger and wasabe 
Japanese Buckwheat Noodles -- with peanut sauce and sesame seeds 
Vermicelli Hand Rolls -- elegantly wrapped in rice sheet, with dipping sauce 
Fried Yellow Bean Cakes -- crispy and delicious Steamed Dumplings filled with mixed vegetables, napa, and tofu, with ginger dipping sauce 
Cup of Soup --  
Choice of either:

Spicy Hot and Sour Soup
Wonton Soup
Miso Soup  

Curry Coconut Vermicelli Noodles with Sweet Potatoes 
Hang's Kale, Tofu & Seitan Supreme
Steamed kale, topped with steamed tofu scallions and seitan, red peppers in black bean basil sauce 
Grasshopper Supreme
Skinless eggplant served with asparagus, spinach, and portabello mushroom in chili basil sauce 
Sweet and Sour Sensation & No Name Mix
Sweet and Sour Battered Tofu & Seitan served with broccoli and sesame seeds 
Crispy Angel Hair Pasta with Mushrooms, Assorted Vegetables and Tofu 
Tofu Eggplant Surprise
Fresh asparagus and eggplant with steamed tofu chunks and peppers in a mild spicy black bean sauce 
Brown Rice Fresh Melons - cubes of freshly cut cantaloupe, honeydew, watermelon 
Jasmin Tea and Britta Purified Water

<a>[masked]</a> - Grasshopper 
Looking forward to seeing you!

results.description:
Join me on a New Year's Day hike beginning at the NH Audobon Massabessic Center. We will explore the area trails for about 2 or 3 hours. Bring micro-spikes and, if there is sufficient snow, snowshoes! Dress appropriately for the weather as this is January in NH! There will be nice views of Lake Massabessic (that you don't see other times of the year on these trails) and animal tracks if there is snow. The Red Arrow restaurant in Londonderry is open on New Year's Day for those who want to get a bite to eat afterwards.

*Rain or Blizzard conditions cancel the hike.*

Massabesic Lake covers around 2, 561 acres and provides the drinking water for Manchester, NH so there is no swimming. The lake holds more than 15 billion gallons of water and is 5.6 miles long with a width of 1.3 miles.
The average depth of the lake is 196 feet and there are 6 main islands around the lake and several smaller islands.
The main islands are Grape, Fletcher, Brown, Birch, Picnic and Loon.

The name Lake Massabesic came from the Native Americans and it means “the place of much water.” One of the most famous chief’s of the state, chief Passaconaway was killed on Lake Massabesic. He was in a canoe headed to Loon Island. The chief had memories of Look Island from when he was younger. A thunderstorm came along and lightning hit the canoe and the chief and the canoe instantly disintegrated. During the American Civil War, NH troops gathered, camped and trained around Lake Massabesic before participating in the war. There is a section of the lake called Battery Point with building remains.

****By signing up and/or attending this hike you agree to the Liability Waiver Below:
Remember: Your Event Organizers  are volunteers. You are solely responsible for your own safety and enjoyment. As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following: this activity involves inherent risks that can cause property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death to participants and/or others; you know and will follow the Hiker Responsibility Code described at <a>www.hikesafe.com; </a>you assume all risk associated with this activity; you are responsible for having the necessary knowledge, skills, abilities, clothing, and equipment to safely participate in this activity; the organizer(s) of this activity is a volunteer; and you for yourself, your heirs, executors, and administrators release, hold harmless, and indemnify organizer(s) and all members of this group from any and all claims for property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death - including those caused by negligence and/or other reason.
results.name: New Year's Day Snowshoe Hike

results.description:
You know that New Year's Resolution you made to loose weight and get more active?????????  Well here's your chance:

Come join us on a guided hike on the first day of  the new year.  There will be three different hikes all leaving at the same time and all guided by Blue Hills staff, beginner, intermediate and expert.  Choose your poison.

Also there will be free hot and hearty soup at noon so come a little early.
All hikes begin at 1:00pm

Meet at the Houghton’s Pond main parking lot on 840 Hillside Street in Milton.
Celebrate the New Year in the Blue Hills! This is the twenty-fourth year of our New Year’s tradition. Join the fun. Warm up with a free cup of hearty soup, and then stretch your legs on a variety of guided hikes suitable for all ages and abilities. A great way to jump start the year! For more information, call[masked]-1802.

Please bring a canned good or two to support Father Bills Homeless Shelter in Quincy.

Download a trail map at this link:

http://www.friendsofthebluehills.org/PDFs/dcr_map_1.pdf
results.name: BLUE HILLS FIRST DAY OF 2016 HIKE

results.description:
Here's the game plan:

1:00 - Toss the disc around, meet folks, be merry

1:10 - Overview of the rules, safety, etc - then divide into teams

1:20 - Play!!!!!!

3:00 - Conclude the meetup and begin socializing.

Here's what we humbly ask of you (works great as a checklist):

Dress for the weather

Bring a white and a dark-colored t-shirt. Grey is evil. If you wear grey you may be asked to wear a light or dark "pinnie of shame."

Arrive on time to be guaranteed a spot in a game

RSVP is recommended so you can be notified if the game is canceled

Bring WATER!

If you are a regular, please consider bringing a buck for the Frisbee Fund

As usual, we will supply the frisbees, cones, first aid supplies (hopefully will never be used) and our pretty smiles. As we periodically mention, all these supplies are paid out-of-pocket by your loving Frisbee organizers and everyone has been so generous with their donations to-date. Thank you and let's keep the dream alive!
results.how_to_find_us: The field is right next to Alewife station on the Red Line. There is also plenty of parking provided no one else is using the field. (Not an issue in the winter.)
results.name: Friday **Afternoon** Ultimate @ Russell Field

results.description:
JourneyDance™ is a dynamic conscious dance form that combines freestyle and structured movement to inspire you to get out of your mind and into your body. We will dance with intention, we will dance carefree, we will dance with fierceness and love. Join me for this opportunity to shed the layers of 2015 to cultivate room for growth in the New Year. Through breath movement and awareness this class will help ground your intentions for 2016.
Register @ www.movewith.com/events/journeydance-new-year-s-day-edition-with-guerda-victor
Investment $15
In the spirit of honoring Haitian Independence Day, traditional Haitian squash soup and other some delights will be served.
results.name: Move into a new story and ground your intention for 2016. JourneyDance Flow!

results.description:
Walk off all that extra food!


this is on, rain or shine or snow. See you there.

We'll do two laps, approximately five miles.

Few things relieve stress better than a some exercise on a nice winter evening.

Let's join some local walking groups for a stroll in a beautiful setting.

If you've still got some energy left, join us on an  earlier walk at Mt. Auburn Cemetery. Parking on Huron Avenue is easy, since the "Permit Parking" rules don't apply on Sunday - just park in any spot on Huron Ave, there will be plenty of them.

If you're coming by bus, take the 71 or 73 bus from Harvard Square and get off at Aberdeen Ave. Walk all the way up Aberdeen until you come to Huron Avenue, we'll be there.

If you have trouble finding us, call me at[masked]

What will this meeting be like? A quiet, reflective and philosophical start of the new year? Or just a good time? Who knows what the fate of this meeting will be...Oh, this is very deep! Of course, there needs to be some interest lest its fate--or Destiny, be the ever possible cancellation :)

results.description:
• THE BOSTON DRUM CIRCLE

• A high-energy, FUN, celebration of drumming and community. For beginners who want to try something new, their friends, experienced drummers, dancers beginners to experts. NO EXPERIENCE REQUIRED!

• We celebrate the traditions - rhythms that have built energy for hundreds of years for celebration, dance, ritual - just plain FUN! As well as whatever you bring to it!

• We gather together every other Friday evening. Check the schedule, grab your drum (or use ours) and have a blast!

We'll have drums to share, and support for newcomers, and energy for everyone.

Recent accolades!

“Great fun! Good rhythms. Very accommodating leader and group for this beginner. Will be back!”

Adrienne S 10/14

It was an amazing experience .. It was nice to feel free from the world and it's problems .. It's was so relaxing, can't wait to drum again ..thanks!

Justin 6/14

Was an awesome experience, I love hand drumming but really the main reason I came was to relieve stress due to family health situations and the circle definitely met my needs. Alan did a great job leading the circle with the drumming and the short history lessons about drumming and Africa. I will be coming back.

Paul 10/13

This Drum Circle is a great stress reliever after a long week of work and I wish it were every Friday night!! Boston Drum Cirlce attracts a wonderful , eclectic group of people that share the common bond of hand drumming. It is always wonderful to have the multi talented Fanta leading the Circle. Her singing, dancing, and drumming are all 5 star. Thank you for a great night of Drumming!

Carla 8/13

We can't wait to meet you! See you soon....

Alan and Fanta

results.description:
Come and join us for an evening of fun and shared energy. How often do we get an opportunity to be real with each other in Boston?

At TurnON, we play three communication games, and you can participate at whatever level feels good to you. Imagine meeting new people in an environment where they feel comfortable to be themselves; a refreshing change from the typical networking or bar conversation. That's what we have created.

TurnON events give you the opportunity to look deeper into yourself, through other people putting quality attention on you, asking questions with genuine curiosity, and then listening - really listening – to your responses. What comes up might surprise you!

It's amazing how connected we can end up feeling - even in a room full of strangers - when we are willing to be authentic. It's like a giant exhale when the rest of the world is asking you to hold it in. In just an hour, you may even forget that you are in Boston.

TurnON Boston is an organization that teaches Orgasmic Meditation, otherwise known as OM. At the end of the evening, we will give you a brief description of the practice of Orgasmic Meditation and information on where to learn more. The games we play at TurnON events are designed to create the visceral sensation of Orgasm/OM in your body, without actually doing the practice (or touching anyone, or removing any clothing!).

$10, payable at the door.

Please arrive on time - we lock the door promptly at 7:10!

Limited non-resident parking is available alongside our building on Dudley Street, or plentiful metered spaces on Mass Ave are only one block away (and free after 6pm). We are a 10-minute walk from the Red Line at Davis Square.


 http://tedxtalks.ted.com/video/TEDxSF-Nicole-Daedone-Orgasm--2
results.how_to_find_us: Entrance is on the corner of Cedar and Dudley Streets.
results.name: TurnON Boston!

results.description:
We will run down Comm Ave in the carriage lane to the Chestnut Hill/BC reservoir, with the option to run around the reservoir before turning around. This is an out and back course so the distance is flexible - you can run however many miles you want!  There are some hills - we will run 3 of the 4 Newton Hills along the Boston Marathon course (if you go at least 8 miles - 4 out and 4 back).

Meet outside at the tables next to Bruegger's and the ATM.  We will leave right at 8:30 AM (especially when it is cold out!).

The pace will vary depending on who shows up.  If there is a wide range of paces, we frequently end up splitting into smaller groups based on pace.  Even if your pace doesn't "match up" with anyone else, meeting up with the group and starting the run with everyone is a great way to get yourself out of bed on those early Saturday mornings!

results.description:
Meet 8:45am in Braintree or Rockland... or wherever you hikers are ... to carpool or meet at trailhead in Alton NH between 11:30am-noon (read through link to directions at bottom of hike description for trailhead info).


This is a moderate 2.5 hour hike with 1,500 ft elevation gain and great views of Lake Winnipesaukee. There are no professional/trained guides going so hikers assume responsibility for themselves -- each should have appropriate footwear, carry own water/snacks, extra traction devices if necessary (poles and microspikes or Yaktraks) and cold/wet weather gear including hat, gloves, dry socks, fleece, windproof outer layer (currently predicting 32 degrees and partly sunny).


Hikers should be in sufficient physical condition to hike several miles, handle steep sections of trail and/or uneven, rocky, slippery surfaces. http://www.franklinsites.com/hikephotos/NewHampshire/straightbackmtn-2010-0728.php

Microspikes or Yaktraks are recommended
